div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THE following play was written above three years ago, and was ſoon after ſhewn to ſome of the principal performers of both houſes. It took its riſe from Miſs ELLIOT'S being adviſed to revive The Country Wife for her benefit the firſt ſeaſon of her engagement at Covent-Garden theatre. That play, upon a review of it, appeared inadmiſſible on account of the obſcenity which diſcolours the whole. The author, or rather the compiler of the enſuing ſcenes, undertook to alter WYCHERLEY's play for Miſs ELLIOT againſt the following winter; but hearing, in the mean time, that Mr. BICKERSTAFF had employed himſelf upon one of WYCHERLEY's pieces, he made it his buſineſs to ſee that gentleman, leſt this writer ſhould interfere with a plan already pre-occupied. He found that the PLAIN DEALER had been Mr. BICKERSTAFF's object, and that there was no danger of claſhing with the ſcheme of any other author. Upon a cloſer examination, therefore, of The Country Wife, it was thought proper to deſert it intirely, and to reſort to MOLIERE, the original maſter whom WYCHERLEY copied. The celebrated comedy of L'Ecole de Femmes appeared too thin of buſineſs, conſiſting moſtly in narrative. To ſupply that deficiency the deſign occurred of making MOLIERE himſelf ſupply the requiſite materials; and for this purpoſe L'ETOURDIE and L'Ecole DE MARIS were called in as auxiliaries. Upon this idea the play was ſoon finiſhed, and it conſiſts of characters, ſituations, and buſineſs, from thoſe three plays, interwoven into one fable, with as much ſkill as a little leiſure in the ſummer time would permit. With the profeſſed deſign of condenſing what appeared to be the beſt of three performances into one play, it was deemed unneceſſary to ſuppreſs any one ſcene of true nature, merely becauſe the author of High Life below Stairs, and ſome other Engliſh writers, might occaſionally be tracked in the ſnow of Moliere.

The play, when finiſhed, was given to Miſs ELLIOT, and it ſo happened, that ſhe had no opportunity of producing it till this ſeaſon. When in September laſt, her bargain both for herſelf and the play was in agitation with Mr. BEARD, the author of theſe ſheets was aſtoniſhed to hear that The Country Girl was actually in rehearſal at Drury Lane, and that the parts had been given out in the ſummer, nay, as faſt as they were written. This, it muſt not be diſſembled, looked like a deſign of foreſtalling the market; eſpecially as it was underſtood, that Miſs ELLIOT and the SCHOOL FOR GUARDIANS, had been offered the ſpring before to the manager of Drury Lane, upon his own terms. A remonſtrance was immediately made to Mr. GARRICK, purporting that he, who had long been a manager of a ſucceſsful theatre, was going to enter into a competition with a young actreſs for the profits of a play. A meeting enſued, where a gentleman of the firſt character for probity and genius, was ſo obliging as to be the arbitrator. Mr. GARRICK there proteſting, that he never heard of Miſs ELLIOT's play till within a few days; it was thereupon determined, that it was, in that caſe, an accidental claſhing, but that a deſign of foreſtalling would have been illiberal and unhandſome. This laſt point of honour Mr. GARRICK ſeemed to learn upon this occaſion.

Both parties were, in conſequence, left to purſue their own intereſts. And now the preſent writer will diſmiſs THE SCHOOL FOR GUARDIANS, after ſaying, that he compoſed it with the moſt diſintereſted principle; and that, if it prove in any degree conducive to the ſervice of a young actreſs, or the public entertainment, he has all the reward he ever propoſed to himſelf.

N. B. An entire ſcene in the ſecond act, page 30. has been omitted ſince the firſt repreſentation, and would have been diſcarded from this edition, but that the greateſt part of the play was printed, before it was acted.

sp.l: MAY I intrude upon your patience for a minute?
Ladies and gentlemen, before the opening of the play,
Juſt to excuſe an accident, which, I hope has no miſchief in it,
I fain, if you'll permit, a word or two would ſay.
I hope you'll not be angry; but we've got no prologue for to night;
And ſo I thought it was beſt to come and tell ye all the truth downright.
I went to Mr. Poet, and I ſpoke to him all I could,
But he ſaid he had not leiſure, tho' I know it's in his power if he would.
"A prologue, ma'am," ſays he!—"Yes, Sir, a prologue if you pleaſe."
And then I did ſo entreat the man, and beg, and pray, and teaze.
I told him, "You know, Sir, what a miſerable plight we all are in,
To frown upon the performers, when pit, box, and gallery begin;
Whu—go the catcalls—dub—dub—dub—each dreadful critick's ſtick
Prólog'— throw him over—won't ye ha ſome orange chips—Prólôgué—Cries o' London—Muſick!"
All this and more I ſaid, but he, determin'd ſtill,
In formal fuſtian thus declar'd his will.
"Oft have I tried"[ſeems puzzled]—ſomething about his ſtile,
And how he felt the Town's indulgent ſmile.
"Were I again to try my ſcanty vein,
I'd beg protection for the feeble ſtrain.
But then to ſue—he paus'd and rubb'd his head—
To ſue—when fam'd MOLIERE the ſtage doth tread,
Were to prophane the manes of the dead.
MOLIERE, of old, and ſtill with rapture ſeen,
Was legiſlator of the comic ſcene.
To bid his SIMPLE GIRL aſſert the ſtage,
And if ſhe pleaſes, ſtrive to mend the age,
This was my motive;—this my only aim;
Heedleſs of gain!—no candidate for fame!
An audience will weigh all in equal ſcales,
For juſtice, and not party, there prevails."
Thus ſpoke Mr.Poet, and then with long ſteps march'd away;
And now I am left alone to apologize for offering you this night's play.
We'll ſtrive to make you laugh, if our aim be not perverted;
Pray, how d'ye find yourſelves?—Are ye in good humour, and willing to be diverted?
If you approve,
The Roſtiad Scribbler then no more I'll dread,
Who points his malice at a woman's head!
Who drop by drop his venom doth diſtil,
While MOTHER-DULLNESS guides the hireling's quill.
Lull'd in her lap, ſtrange wonders he deſcries,
And TERENCE ſeems—a Frenchman to his eyes!
From thence he iſſues ſoul decrees on plays,
Adorns with ſcandal, and lampoons with praiſe.
One ſmile from you defeats the ſland'rer's aim;
His calumny, like your APPLAUSE, is fame.
From your applauſe our mimic glories riſe;
In pleaſing you my whole ambition lies.

lg.l: LAdies, your ſervant—Servant, gentlemen all—
The ſame good folks to you—both great and ſmall.
Here's MARY ANN again:—but that an't fair,
To jeer a ſimple girl you might forbear.
Who knows, ſince married,—tho' you laugh and gaze,
But MARY ANN may learn your London ways?
May ape your faſhions, ſince you've ſhewn her how,
And drop the maſk at once—as I do now.
Thus you behold,—whatever the condition,
To new extremes how eaſy the tranſition.
'Tis ſo thro'life:—to town from country fairs
The clown comes up, and gapes, and laughs, and ſtares!
Give him a liv'ry,—whims unknown before!
He learns his maſter's follies to do o'er;
He drinks,— • u •• s coxcomb, and betts five to four.
Pray, may I, ladies, touch your modiſh life,
And ſhew good ſenſe and faſhion there at ſtrife?
"Oh! do Miſs Elliot, ſays a prude with ſpite,
Pull'em to pieces; bring their faults to light;
Pulling to pieces is my dear delight."
Why then each fair one ſeems a diff'rent creature
From what ſhe's meant, and traveſties her nature.
Proud of defects, FLIRTILLA ſwims along,
Politely weak, and elegantly wrong.
Thro' the gay round of time her only care
To fix the patch, and guide a ſtraggling hair.
Lady CAMILLA, form'd to ſeize the rein,
To rival John, and ſmack along the plain;
In London ſickens with diſſembled airs,
And "help me—help me up theſe odious ſtairs."
Nature's beſt gifts we all with pride diſclaim;
We liſp, we totter, deaf, and blind, and lame.
The tongue indeed we women ne'er confine;
—Scandal's too dear a pleaſure to reſign.
Scandal, and cards, tea, mirth, and ſpleen, a ball,
Comus!—the monkey too!—and there's the life of'all.
A life of whim!—till from ſhe faded eye,
And wither'd form, the trembling graces fly.
There's a true picture!—how do ye like it, ladies?
How is the light? and how do ye think the ſhade is?
A copy hence our ſimple girl may make;
Unleſs ſhe ſhould this wiſer counſel take,
Be rul'd by reaſon for your beauty's ſake.
Reaſon ſtill gives to radiant eyes their grace,
Warren's imperial milk—for ev'ry face.
Beauty, ye fair, may forge the lover's chain;
But the mind's charms your empire muſt maintain.

div.head: THE School for Guardians, A COMEDY.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: BUT I won't be told; I won't reaſon about it; I won't be anſwered; I won't hear a word.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I have done, Sir—you have proved it to demonſtration, by the ſame ſort of logick that was uſed by one of the wits of Charles the lld's. time to his dog, when he was too lazy to beat him, "I wiſh you well married, and ſettled in the country"—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
There again now; don't enrage me; I have ſome whimſical humours about me, that let me tell you, Sir—and I can be very peremptory, if I pleaſe—What? when my neighbour Strickland and I have agreed the matter!—a young lady with a fair fortune in hand, and ſeven hundred a year in expectancy, as pretty a reverſion as any in Hampſhire!— and am I now to be told, "She does not ſuit my taſte,—ſhe is not handſome?" and ſo I am to be
waſting my breath with you, about a complection, a noſe, and a lip!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: If you would but leave thoſe matters to me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: But I tell you no; I won't leave thoſe matters to you—Beauty is the laſt thing I deſire to ſee in my family—Your mother, peace be to her, was as ugly a woman as you ſhall ſee in a ſummer's day; and what do you think I married her for?— for your good, Sir—for the good of my children—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And pray, Sir, which of ye does this ſide-box face of mine take after?

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: You ſhall take nothing after me, that you may depend upon, unleſs you prove obedient to my will and pleaſure.—I'll not leave you a foot of land—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I hope you'll live to enjoy it yourſelf, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I'll give my fortune to found a new college, where it is not wanted—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I hope you'll live to enjoy it yourſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I'll cut you off with a ſhilling to buy you an halter—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I hope you'll live to enjoy it yourſelf, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall, tho' you ſay it with a ſort of a dry look between juſt and earneſt—But don't talk to me of beauty again; I never knew any good come of it; beauty is like fine fruit, only fit to draw a parcel of flies about it—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And ſo I muſt ſet my teeth on edge with crab-tree apples—But where would be the harm, Sir, if purely for the good of my family, I were to marry a lady of ſome ſhare of beauty, only juſt to croſs the ſtrain a little, and ſettle a ſhape and a feature upon the iſſue of our marriage?

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
Settle your wife's fortune upon 'em—Look ye, Sir;—my purſe ſtrings will never open,—
not a ſhilling of my money ſhall you touch, till you pay your reſpects to Miſs Strickland—now you know my reſolution—What a graceleſs look there is! ruin yourſelf if you will—follow your own courſes, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Your moſt obedient very humble ſervant, Sir,—you may depend that—I ſhall chuſe for myſelf—Briſk! why don't you anſwer, ſirrah!—Why Briſk!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: We have been pretty handſomely lectured here this morning, Briſk!—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, we have had wherewithal to edify by—I ſuppoſe, we ſhall lie at Tom Tilbury's at Bagſhot to-night, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Tom Tilbury's, Sir—only juſt to break the neck of our journey, for I ſuppoſe now, you'll drop all thoughts of this other lady—I forget her name—Ay! miſs Mary Ann Richley—She has no chance now, I reckon, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Why, you ſenſeleſs numſkull!—as ſure as I am Charles Brumpton, Eſq ſhe ſhall be Mrs. Brumpton; and upon the death of my very good father, ſhe'll be a baronet's lady, that's all—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: And yet there is ſome truth in what Sir Theodore ſays—Beauty is but a frail periſhable ſort of a commodity; and if you are diſinherited for it, the lady's charms will not pay your poor ſervant, Briſk, his board-wages; a feature, or a ſmile can't go to market; a pawn-broker will lend nothing upon the tip of an ear: though indeed ſhe may mortgage her perſon; but that I take it will be for her own advantage; we ſhall get nothing but a comely pair of horns by it, Sir, with ſubmiſſion—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Why you talk a frothy kind of nothing at a tolerable rate, Briſk—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: I have ſhewn you one ſide of the medal, now behold the reverſe, Sir—When you marry an ugly woman, there is no great pleaſure in beholding her, and to be ſure when you look at her, you'll be apt to murmur to yourſelf—for all purpoſes of joy one may cut as deſirable an object out of an old tapeſtry-hanging—but then the woman has ſome valuable parchments, ſuch as leaſes, bonds, and mortgages; and I, Sir, ſhall live in tolerable plight with you, which to ſo good a maſter—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Leave prating, ſirrah, and do as I ordered you—put on your farmer's dreſs, go directly to the object I adore—let her know you are come from her guardian in the country, and have his orders to take her home under your care—convey her ſafe to my arms, and I ſhall reward you—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: No arguing with me—about it ſtreight—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: You know how many blanketings and blows I have ſuffered in your ſervice, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Sirrah, no words—go and ſee who's at the door—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: You have marred many an excellent plot of mine, Sir—you know you cannot help meddling, when I undertake a ſcheme—If you'll promiſe me, Sir, not to—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Will you ſee who's at the door?

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: I am gone, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—I ſhall moſt certainly carry her off—How Sir Theodore will be aſtoniſhed when he finds ſhe is an heireſs!—Ha! ha!—it is the pleaſanteſt adventure—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Brumpton, good morrow!—always in ſpirits, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
My dear Belford, nothing depreſſes my ſpirits—though you thought they were too high laſt night, and were for letting me a little blood. Death!
man, you make nothing of diſplaying an ell of ſwordblade in defence of your miſtreſs's top-knot.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Why you know I love too tenderly to bear the teſt of raillery—it is the infirmity of my temper; why would you put me to it?—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And you that know my turn of mind, why would you be angry with me?—I am happily a follower of the laughing philoſopher—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Po! prithee, man, don't be ſuch a coxcomb.—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Prithee, don't you be ſo moroſe, ſo ſour, ſo diſcontented a ſpirit—But if in your phraſe I am a coxcomb, with all my heart, i'faith: but take this along with you—what you mean as a term of reproach, I receive as a compliment to the materials nature has been pleaſed to compound in this happy frame of mine—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Po! Po! running on at the old rate—If ſelf-applauſe be philoſophy, you have a comfortable ſhare.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I have, Sir, and while my happineſs is preſerved by it, keep you the gravity and good ſenſe, that make you too refined to be pleaſed, too wiſe to be merry, and too knowing to be contented.—I am in a fair way to be ſucceſsful, without any trouble at all;—you are likely to be moſt ſcurvily diſappointed after a world of pains—An humble bow, which my dancing-maſter taught me, while I laughed at him, a faſhionable coat, for which, if my taylor is ever paid he will laugh at me,—an intriguing ſnuff-box,— and an apt valet de chambre, all theſe make love for me, and—.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: And you aſſume the merit of the conqueſt—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Oh! yes, when the trouble is over, I take the reward.—Did you ever know a general officer, who, when the horſe and the foot, and the right and left wing have carried the day for him, did not claim to himſelf both the honour and the booty?
But you make a toil of a pleaſure—love, which to me is a ſcene of delight, to you is a drudgery; your temper grows as ſour, as a prude's when the ſermon is long; and as hot as a Welſhman's, if you laugh at his pedigree; or a profeſſed ſharper's, if you doubt his honour, after he has cogged the dice, and picked your pocket of your money.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Why I own I am piqued and naturally. If any friend of mine, out of mere ſpleen, ſpeak detractingly of the perſon I admire: it were baſe infidelity in love not to defend her, when ſhe is diſparaged—my every thought is dedicated to her.—Abſent I ſee her, hear her, and my imagination gloats for ever on her charms.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And you are ſo eaſily alarmed, that little difficulties are the Alps and Pireneans in your way—Now my faith in theſe matters removes mountains—But indeed in all things we are oppoſite characters—If a tradeſman brings you in a bill and preſſes for payment, 'Sdeath! does the ſcoundrel doubt my honour? does he mean to affront me?—Now I, when my father ſuffered me to be arreſted, went cheerfully into confinement, and diverted myſelf for three weeks together with the bum-bailiff's character—In the buſineſs of our ſofter paſſions, the ſame humour purſues us—you write ſtudied letters to your Dulcinea, I am written to;—you ſigh, I ſing;—you fret I am gay;—you, upon a diſappointment, Furies, death, and rage—there is no enduring this—life is grown a burden—damnation! I burſt into a laugh, and what a whimſical world we live in—ha! ha!—But come, I will hear your melancholy ſtory,—Well, the old dragon I ſuppoſe watches the Heſperian fruit.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: He does, Sir—he keeps her locked up as a miler does his gold, not to be made uſe of till his death, and then to fall into hands that won't know the value of it—Its love's laſt ſhift with me; ſhe is inacceſſible, and her guardian, old Lovibond, propoſes to marry her himſelf.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And ſo, like the tyrant of old, intends to tack a living and dead body together.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Even ſo—my dear Brumpton, there ſhould be an act of parliament to hinder theſe old fellows from ſtopping the propagation of the ſpecies.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You are too hard upon 'em—they are ſeldom guilty of that miſchief;—I have known 'em have twins at a birth; that is, when ſome ſuch coxcomb as myſelf gives them a helping hand;—and then the old fellow cocks his hat upon it, and totters about ſo vigorouſly, wondering how the babes reſemble him in every particular; whilſt the mother knows, that ſhe followed the example of the Grecian painter, and took a feature from every one of her acquaintance.—If he prevents your marrying her, take your revenge that way.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Prophanation!—her virtue, Sir—beſides the world could never repair the loſs—her heart I am ſure is mine—I uſed to viſit there—but now no admittance; an evidence on the crown ſide in a meſſenger's hands is not better ſecured.

sp.speaker: Brompton.
sp.p: Now my buſineſs goes on without any trouble or difficulty. My old dragon is in the country, and has left his fair ward, the ſweeteſt girl, my dear Belford.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You deſcribed her yeſterday but few removes from a downright idiot.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Pardon me—ſhe is ſimple indeed—But ſuch a ſimplicity!—It juſt ſerves to ſhew that injuſtice has been done her in her education, but in her every turn ſhe gives ſuch tokens of ſenſibility!—She has beauty without knowing it;—certain wild graces, rather than accompliſhments, and talents inſtead of ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Po! Po!—a mere ruſtic beauty.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
There now, derogating from her merit, and yet I am calm!—the truth is ſhe has been brought up in the country, and wickedly kept in ignorance,
that ſhe might fall an eaſy prey to her guardian—But I have raiſed a ſpirit in her.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: And how the devil did you gain acceſs to her?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I was going to tell you—Old Neſtor's out of town, and has left her in the care of the two verieſt ſimpletons that ever whiſtled for want of thought at a country fair—But gold, Sir, gold, that ſpeaks all languages, and adapts itſelf to all capacities, has pleaded moſt eloquently for me—But, come, I poſitively muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Nay, if it muſt be ſo—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: My dear Belford, Cupid direct your arrows—
sp.l: I ſee her every day, and all the day,
And every day is ſtill but as the firſt,
So eager am I ſtill to ſee her more.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And but this moment returned, Mr. Oldcaſtle!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Juſt this moment ſtepped out of the machine—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well! and now I ſuppoſe you have prudently laid aſide all thoughts of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ha! you are a comical man, brother Lovibond,—I have taken my meaſures; to-morrow makes me a bridegroom, and my fair ward Miſs Mary Ann, a bride—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And a little time will make you—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Happy—tho', by that ſignificant look, you have your doubts.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have Sir—I have a ſhrewd gueſs that—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Then you'll be out in your gueſs—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I wiſh your horns a'n't out firſt—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Well ſaid, and without any apprehenſion for yourſelf; you are ſtill determined to marry Mary Ann's ſiſter Harriet I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: That's quite another buſineſs; what I do, is no rule for your actions—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: It is as I ever ſaid—each man is ſtill looking at the hump upon his neighbour's back, but never thinks of caſting an eye over his own ſhoulder—I warrant me now you, in your grand climacteric, will tell me I am old—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Full ten years before me in the race of life—beſides, you are an old batchelor;—a ſtranger to the ways of wedlock—I am enured to the ſervice—your ſiſter, Mr. Oldcaſtle, could have told you what a deſperate good huſband I was—But, lack a day!— you begin late—mercy on your forehead, ſay I, mercy on your forehead!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ha! ha! how blind ſome people are when they have taken a thing in their heads!—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well! well! laugh on—but you that have been for ever a cenſor of your neighbours, for ever fleering and jibing at the married life—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: And a pleaſant topic it is!—Why matrimony affords a little comedy in every family one knows—But the education I have given Mary Ann—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Is the worſt in the world—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The very beſt!—I have trained her up in plain ſimplicity—woman's wit teems with contrivances to diſgrace her huſband—yet you would educate Harriet in this profligate town!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay, and I have taught her to know right from wrong.—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Right from wrong! you have ruined the girl—have not you indulged her in every whimſy this fertile town affords?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have ſhewn her the world—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Have not you carried her to plays?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: To ſee folly ridiculed—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: To profligate comedies?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: The ſtage is the ſchool of virtue—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The ſchool of ſin and impudence!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Where vice undergoes the laſh of ſatire—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Where vice is made alluring, provoking—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Where young ladies may learn—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The uſe of dark-cloſets, back-ſtairs, and ladders of rope.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Where they may learn to put on the veil of modeſty.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: To put on the breeches, and eſcape from their guardians!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Where they are taught to reſpect grey-headed authority!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: To make a cuckold of authority!—I know the ways of 'em all!—their cards, routs, operas, Soho-aſſemblies, all contrivances to excite curioſity, kindle deſire, prompt inclination, and ſend 'em all dancing a jig to deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Common-place invective!—Harriet will know how to avoid—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: She will know how to deceive you—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: She will have too much honour —

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: She will have too much wit—now Mary Ann has no wild notions, and of courſe no dangerous curioſity.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Her curioſity is to come—ſhe'll fall a prey to the firſt powdered coxcomb that bows to her—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Her ſimplicity will preſerve her—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: But when the ſerpents of this town begin to whiſper in her ear—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p:
They'll have no opportunity—She is ſnug in a little box of an houſe, which I have taken in the name of Mr. Biddulph. I have another lodging in my own name, where I do buſineſs.—Nobody will ſee her; and when the nine day's wonder is over,
I ſhall pack off to the country, and ſo eſcape from impertinence.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well! well!—I can't but laugh at your ſyſtem of education! ha! ha!—Marry her if you will;—and then on account of your age and infirmities, you may do the buſineſs of your office by deputy—Ha! ha! a plan of ſimplicity!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Brother Lovibond, a good day to you—I wiſh you ſucceſs—Ha! ha! a town-education for a young girl!—
Ha! ha! poor man tottering to bed to a young wife—I'll go home to my own Harriet—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and confuſion! my dull brain can deviſe nothing—hey! is not that old Argus Centoculi with all his eyes out?—Mr. Lovibond,—a ſight of you—what have you been out of town?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: No, the builders are carrying the town out of town I think, and ſo, a body need not move out of London for country air—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: How charmingly you look!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What you call a green old age—I am not like the young rakes about this town, who decay in their prime, and are fourſcore at five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Ay! you have lived upon the intereſt of your conſtitution, and have not out-run the principal—I have had the honour of knocking at your door ſeveral times—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I know it—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: But no body at home—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I know that too—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I want to loſe a little more money to you at back-gammon—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have left it off—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Well! well! I'll come and eat a bit of mutton with you—How ſtand you for to-day?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What an hurry he is in? [aſide] I have an unlucky engagement—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Well! I'll take a morſel of ſupper—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well puſhed! [aſide.] I have left off ſuppers—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: So beſt—I'll be with you at breakfaſt in the morning—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have taken to breakfaſting at the coffee-houſe—One meets with very ſenſible people at the coffee-houſe, and hears men praiſed for being out of place, and abuſed for being in place,—and a huge deal of news, that's very entertaining in the morning; and all a damned lie in the evening.—Your ſervant—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: But the fair Miſs Harriet—how does ſhe do?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: There he has touched the right ſtring at laſt [aſide] I'll let her know how kind you are.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Nay, don't fly ſo ſoon—I am to give you joy, I hear—you are to make Miſs Harriet happy, I underſtand.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Oh! no; they talk at random—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Yes, yes; come, you have taught her all her accompliſhments, and are now to teach her the art of love—ha! ha! Mr. Lovibond—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I profeſs no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Yes, yes, come—ſhall I dance at your wedding—you'll truſt her with me in a country dance, and ſee that lovely boſom heave in ſweet diſorder, and riſe as if it wooed your hand to touch it, e'er it fails again—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—you talk looſely—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Then when muſick wakens every gentler paſſion, and the ſprightly romping has called forth all her bloom; then you'll lead her off, conſenting trembling, doubting, bluſhing—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—come, I'll go and dine with you—"The world muſt be peopled, you know"— Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Well! well! let him be obſtinate, if he will—I muſt ſtep, and ſee how Mary Ann has fared theſe ten days, ſince I have been in the country.—Let me ſee, what's o'clock?—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: How her old gaoler will look when he returns to town, and finds ſhe has broke priſon! I ſhall be deemed the very Machiavel of intrigue!—Hey! is not that Mr. Oldcaſtle?—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Mr. Brumpton!—I rejoice to ſee you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: My dear friend, you are come in the very criſis of my fate, in that dear extatic moment, when to the natural vivacity of a gay, giddy temper like mine, ten thouſand circumſtances conſpire to lift me to the upper regions of delight, which, together with the felicity of encountering the only man in the world, that—I muſt take breath—I am faint with bliſs—it is too much—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ay! your fever is pretty high, I ſee—recover your ſenſes a little—and tell me at your leiſure what is this mighty buſineſs—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Oh! buſineſs of ſuch a nature—the Gods are now in council upon it,—I expect Mercury every moment in the ſhape of my man Briſk, to let me know that the nectared ſweets that dwell upon the lips of a certain lady are intended for a wild unthinking coxcomb, as the world is pleaſed to call me—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: To be ſure—you are in requeſt among the ladies, no doubt—Now will he lie like an attorney's clerk [aſide] You are going to help ſome worthy gentleman to an heir to his eſtate, I warrant me—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I have done ſome ſervice in that way; but the truth is, I am now going to help my father to a grandſon.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Going to be married!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: This day may perhaps crown my joys—ſome certain fumblers at this end of the town, who were a little alarmed at the proportions of this leg, intend to light their windows upon it; the court of aldermen are preparing all demonſtrations of joy; and their unhappy wives are going into deep mourning upon the occaſion!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The ſame confident fop he ever was! well, and my friend Sir Theodore, what ſays he to all this?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You know his way; the ſame old crabed humour—he has made a match for me elſewhere with one that—I would not deny the lady her merit—ſhe preſerves pickles well, and is a very notable keeper of accounts—the woman will do very well of a long winter's evening to ſay, Bleſs you when you ſneeze—but—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: She has a fortune, I preſume—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Does not want acres—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: And you prefer one without any

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You miſtake me! ſhe's an heireſs; it is not clear that ſhe is of age, but as ſoon as ſhe comes to years of diſcretion—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Then ſhe may play the fool as faſt as ſhe will—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: By chuſing me, you think, ſhe will give a ſpecimen of her folly.—Ha! ha! I have paſſed many hours with her of late; ſhe is beautiful as an angel—Now, my dear Sir, you can do me the moſt eſſential ſervice—you have great influence over Sir Theodore,—I dare not break this matter to him myſelf, but a word from you—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: And has ſhe really an eſtate?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: A very fine one;—a large number of acres, and a coal-pit upon one of the manors—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I profeſs I like your taſte—ha! ha! The coal-pit whitens her ſkin, and ſhe may hereafter wear a few of her own acres in each ear—I will ſee my old friend about this, and will poſitively promote your welfare.—He ſhall agreee to it, and—But how did you bring this about, pray?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: An old way that I have—I came, ſaw, and conquered—I ſaw her at her window—ſuch blooming ſweetneſs! Her eyes were through my heart at once—love inſpired me with due courage—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: That was right—a bold ſtroke for a wife—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I drank tea with her the very next evening—I muſt indeed admit, that her underſtanding is not the moſt accompliſhed—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: So beſt—never marry a wit—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: She is at preſent rather in a ſtate of ignorance; but from thoſe blue eyes ſhe occaſionally darts ſuch glances, as beſpeak a mind ſuſceptible of the higheſt refinement.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Where does ſhe live?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: In the very next ſtreet—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What that ſtreet there?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Yes, that—under the care of the verrieſt muck-worm—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: He means me, I fear [aſide.] and her name, pray—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Miſs Mary Ann Richley—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Wounds! what a diſcovery here is!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Her guardian's name is Biddulph—perhaps you may know him—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: No, not I—the young rake-hell!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: He means to abuſe his truſt, and confine youth and beauty within the arms of age and uglineſs.—There's an old rogue for you!—Does not he deſerve to be hanged?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What a young villain!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I beg your pardon—I did not hear—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am ſeized with an ugly fit of coughing— [coughs.] But you ſhould conſider—the marriage-act is very ſtrict, and requires the conſent of prudent people—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Po! that's nothing—abuſe Scotland as they will, it enables us to evade the laws of England.—My dear Mr. Oldcaſtle, you have promiſed me you'll ſpeak to my father—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ay! I'll keep my word—He ſhall certainly know how you are going on—I'll do you that good turn, you may depend—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: My dear good friend, it is ſo lucky that I met with you—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am heartily glad I met you, indeed—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Well now, adieu!—Oh! but I forgot to tell you—She'll be mine this very day.—Briſk, my fellow,—who is a footman of talents, is to go to her as a tenant from the country, come to town with old Biddulph's commands to carry her down with him in the fly.—She is ſo ſimple ſhe will believe it; and the oafs about her will bite like gudgeons—and ſo—ha! ha!—I kindle into rapture;—I muſt fly to know the happy tidings—and ſo fare ye well—you'll ſpeak to my father—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I'll do for you there—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: A million of thanks to you—Ha! ha! is not this a charming adventure?—Ha! ha!—Did you ever know ſo happy a rogue?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I never knew ſo abandoned a young profligate, nor ſo damned an adventure!—If the fellow is lurking about my doors, I'll ſwear a robbery againſt him—If I get ſight of him, I'll deſcribe him from head to foot; and ſwear he ſtole a horſe in Northamptonſhire—I have not a moment to loſe,—and then, my young madam, bag and baggage away into the country.

div.head: ACT II.
div.p: HO! ho! ye powers of laughter, you will ſhake me to pieces one day or other!—Poor Briſk!— What a jade's trick madam Fortune has play'd him!—He writes me here— [going to read.] All the poor devil's ill ſtars muſt have been combined againſt him!—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Yes, all my ill ſtars are combined, ſure enough!—Oh! Brumpton! I have ſeen her guardian, that ſuperannuated iniquity! but he defeats my happineſs, and croſſes all my ſchemes.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You were admirably employed, my dear Belford—Ha! ha!—"Cato's a proper perſon to entruſt a love-tale with."

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You mirth is unſeaſonable, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Nay, if you will run about like a great boy to catch old birds with chaff, when you ought to ſeize the young unfledged one in its neſt; why the conſequence will be, that, like a great blubbering boy, you'll come back with your finger in your eye, "I don't know what to do—I can't catch it—I can't—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! inſulted thus—draw, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Not I, truly—I am otherwiſe diſpoſed—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Defend yourſelf, or I'll diſpoſe of you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Well! kill me, if you will—I'll die laughing like Pierre in the tragedy—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Po! your meanneſs and your folly make you unworthy of my ſword—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Ay! that's right—and now in due form, what has provoked you?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! Sir, becauſe your affairs are in a tolerable train, am I to be made your ſport? Oh! you don't know what it is to be diſappointed in the tendereſt paſſion—

sp.speaker: Brumpton
sp.p: But I am diſappointed, and in the tendereſt paſſion too; and yet it was that very diſappointment I was laughing at; and not my friend—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: And are your purpoſes croſſed too?—My dear brother ſufferer—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Ay! now I am unfortunate—Oh! the human mind!—Yes, Sir, I am diſappointed—Ha! ha!—Briſk is in a devil of a pickle! He went in diſguiſe to carry off my little goddeſs for me—Somebody that reſembles him has committed a robbery in Northamptonſhire—They have charged Briſk, and he writes me here, that they have carried him before Mr. Carbuncle, the wine-merchant, who deals out bad law, and adulterate port, to all St. Anne's pariſh—Briſk will be chronicled in miſerable elegy, clubbed by two poets upon a flock-bed in the Old Jewry;—the hiſtorians of Grub-ſtreet are already preparing "The Life and Converſation of Jeremy Briſk, who was born of honeſt parents"—Ha! ha! poor devil! I muſt go to his aſſiſtance—

sp.speaker: Mittimus.
sp.p: Here, bring the priſoner this way—A great pity, maſter Squeezum, that Mr. Carbuncle is not at home—This fellow will be carried to another ſhop, I fear—

sp.speaker: Squeezum.
sp.p:
No, no; that ſhan't be—I have found another juſtice to ſit for him—a gentleman who has
been in the commiſſion many years—He was going by in his chariot, but I ſtopped him—Here, bring in the priſoner—

div.stage: Enter Briſk, dreſſed as a country fellow.

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Nay, good chriſtian people—gentlemen—neighbours—I never was in Northamptonſhire in my life—I am a poor, harmleſs, innocent fellow—I always had a mortal averſion to a cart—I never ſaw one in my days but it was better than a ſermon to me—

div.stage: Enter Sir Theodore, with a Letter in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Well! well! I am not fond of acting, but rather than juſtice ſhould be at a ſtand—The fellow anſwers the deſcription!—Sirrah, what can you ſay for yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Hi! hi! what ſhall I ſay?—your humble ſervant, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Free and familiar!—mind what you ſay, this is a ſerious buſineſs—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Dear heart, Sir, does not your honour know me?—your ſon's faithful and honeſt ſervant, Briſk—

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Briſk!—what rogue's trick have you been playing, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Your honour knows, Sir, I have not been out of your houſe any time theſe ſix weeks paſt—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: And why in this diſguiſe, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Nothing but a frolick, Sir—a mere freak of my young maſter's, Sir, and nothing more—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Commit him for further examination—Raſcal, I will know the whole—make out a warrant—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Sir, Sir,—I—you ſhall hear it all—the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Very well, and if you dare attempt to deceive—Clear the room, and leave us to ourſelves [exeunt all the reſt.] If you tell me a ſingle falſehood—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Not a tittle, Sir—the fact is, Sir—my maſter is in love deſperately with a young lady from the country—He ſays ſhe is an heireſs, Sir, but I own I don't believe it—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Go on—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: And, Sir, I was to go in this dreſs, and ſo to carry her off, and deliver her over to him—That's the ſhort and the long of it, Sir, as I am a ſinner.—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: And as you value your ears, this is the truth?

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Oh! upon honour, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Hark-ye, ſirrah!—you know the oak that ſtands near my houſe in the country—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Perfectly well, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: It has been the reformer of manners twenty miles round the country—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Ay! Sir, it has been felt with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I have ordered a good cudgel to be lopped for me, and, if there is any deception in this, thy ſhoulders ſhall anſwer.

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Every word moſt religiouſly true, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Very well! may be ſo—it has an air—I am glad I have found this out—The prodigal! the blockhead!—you may go home, Sir—I can take upon me to diſcharge you from the ſuſpicion you ſtand under here—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—and I ſhall ever—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: And if I ever detect you in any more plottings—if you are again the confederate of that abſurd blockhead!

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Tranſport me, Sir, if ever again—Well off, Briſk, well off!—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: So—ſo—I have found out the young graceleſs, have I?—mighty well! and if I don't exert the authority of a father—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: To be locked up in this manner with an old rogue of a guardian!—Mr. Belford! Mr. Belford! why won't you be my deliverer?—He knows I like him; I have told him ſo a thouſand times; that is my eyes have told him ſo—And yet he undertakes nothing—One would think the young men of this age have not hearts in their boſoms bigger than pin's heads!—Ah! my dear protector!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: My bloſſom!—my lovely little ward! to-morrow makes you the queen of my heart; and your will ſhall be a law to me.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: You only flatter me;—you won't let yourſelf be ruled by me—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I ſhall live under your abſolute command, roſe-bud!—But you muſt be mild in authority, for you know—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, I know how tender you have been—your confining me here for ſo many days is to me a proof of the tendereſt love.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Yes, it is a mark of my affection—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: There are many reaſons why I ſhould not venture abroad—more than you deam of—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: You alarm me—what reaſons?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Why the danger is—no—you'll be for fighting the odious man—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: No—I'll not fight—I'll live for you—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But will you follow my advice, and ſpeak to him calmly, without paſſion?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I will—Let me hear—what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Why that Mr. Belford, whoſe viſits you uſed to encourage—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have not liked him a good while—what of him?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh! he's a wicked man—He has vile deſigns in his head, and would fain have me liſten to his propoſals—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: The impudence of the young men of this age!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Your back is no ſooner turned, than he raps at the door, and at the windows, and diſgraces me with all the neighbours—my character will be ruined [pretends to cry] unleſs you find ſome method to—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, my ſweet—I'll bar my doors, and you ſhan't ſtir out this twelvemonth—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: That won't do—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Then you ſhall never go out at all—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: That's ſome comfort—But in the mean time to have my reputation blaſted by an abandoned libertine [ſhe cries.] Caeſar's wife ſhould not only be virtuous, but free from ſuſpicion—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: The ſenſible girl! this is owing to her education—her ſiſter Mary Ann could not make ſuch a remark—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Well! well!—you don't love me—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Yes, but I do—I'll go and ſwear the peace againſt him—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I wiſh you would—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I'll do it directly—I'll let him know by a juſtice's warrant that Caeſar's wife is not to be trifled with—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: And pray tell him, I hate him—that he may come as often as he will under my window, but it will be to no purpoſe, for I ſhall not endeavour to let him in—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: He ſhall hear it—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Let him know that tho' he is young and handſome, that all his charms are loſt upon me—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I'll do it—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
Tell him you have been a father to me,—
that I conſider you ſtill as my father, and that I think it unnatural to love giddy young men, when I can be ſo much better off with you.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: He ſhall hear it on every ſide of his ears—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Ay, but without loſs of time, if you love me—I ſhan't be eaſy till he knows my mind—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Nor I—it is fit he ſhould know your mind—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, and tell him, if he ſhould come when you are out, not all his winning ways ſhall prevail on me run away with him—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: You have charmed me; tranſported me; raviſhed me; get up-ſtairs—I'll ſeek him this moment—ha! ha!—this all ſprings from her good ſenſe—this is knowing right from wrong—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Be ſure you tell him every word—and if Mr. Belford does but underſtand every word, as I intend it, then I may ſtill wing my flight to his dear arms—A new ſcheme this of mine!—But love inſpired it, and love may crown it with ſucceſs—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Bridget—the gentleman's generous enow, for a matter o'that.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: And pray, Peter, do the London folk always give money to the like of we, as often as they come in or out of the houſe?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Ay! zure, and the ſarving folk call it vails. Why, Bridget, poor ſervants would not be able to ape all their maſter's follies, and powder like fine gentry, and curſe and ſwear like lords, an ſo be every body did not give at ſtreet door more than any thing they get in the houſe is worth.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: La! well that's pure, ſure enow!

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: As to me, do ye zee, I does not care how often the gentleman comes, and for a matter o'that, I does not care how long maſter ſtays in the country—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Theſe London ways are comical, that's for ſure. [a rap at the door] More griſe to the mill—go and open the door, Peter—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Go yourſelf, an you go to that—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: I ſhall budge none, not I.—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Nor, I, faith and troth!

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Law, how can you be ſo croſs—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: You put all upon me, that's your way—who's at the door—
open the door, you varlets, open the door.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Oh! it's maſter—I'll go—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Maſter!—then I'll go—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Stand out of the way, can't you?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Stand away yourſelf—I be ready—ben't I!

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Farther a field, will you?
Within there, open the door, I ſay—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Call here to Peter—he won't let a body—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: No body ſhall but I— [opens the door] Servant maſter.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Welcome home, maſter.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Why am I to wait thus?

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: It was all his doings—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: It was all her doings as well as I.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Peace, numſkulls!—how is every body at home?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Charmingly well.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: All in pure health, praiſe for every thing; and Miſs Mary Ann ſings about the houſe like a little bird in a cage.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Has not ſhe been melancholy ſince I went into the country?

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: No, Lord love her, not ſhe—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Yes!—how terrible he looks!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Did not ſhe long for my return?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Hugeouſly! ſo we did all—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Vixen! jade! villain! raſcal!

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: I'm down o'my knees—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: So be I—merciful father, how—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You have obeyed my orders, have you? That ſcoundrel that was lurking here about my houſe, he is ſent to Newgate by this time

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Don't ſend I to Newgate, pray—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: He'll murder us both, as ſure as a gun—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What you are a ſneaking away, are you? Oh! it's all too true—come back, or—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: No, Sir—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! Mary Ann! Mary Ann!—I could never have imagined—call Mary Ann hither—

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Yes, Sir

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Now will they plot, and put their heads together—Mary Ann!—Marry Ann!—Oh! here ſhe comes.

div.stage: Enter Mary Ann, playing with a cup and ball.

sp.p: Three children ſliding on the ice—ſo, you be come, I ſee—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Yes, I am come home—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Better late than never—I began to think as how you had forgot poor I—I expected you all the live long, long day, ſo I did, and there did not go by a coach or a cart, or an horſe or an aſs, but I thought it was you—ah! I am glad you're come—what's the matter?—ben't you well?—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Fatigued after my journey—you have been very well, I hope, ſince I left you—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Oh! yes, purely—neither ſick nor ſorry not I—by goles, that is not true neither, for laſt night—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Laſt night!—what of laſt night?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Little Pompey barked ſo all night long, I could not ſleep a wink—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Is that all?—you have not been out any where, have you?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Out!—law, where ſhould I go?— I don't like going out in this ſtrange outlandiſh place—I like the country better by half—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Well! well! you ſhall go back ſoon.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: But then mayn't I go and ſee ſiſter Harriet firſt?—an ill natured thing that's what ſhe is—ſhe has not been to ſee poor I ever ſince I came to the great town.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee her—ſo you paſſed your time very merrily!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Oh! never better in all my days—but you don't ſeem glad to ſee a body—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I am glad to ſee you—the little Jezabel won't tell me a word [aſide]—ſhall I tax her with it directly, or wait a little longer to ſee her cunning?—let you and I go and chat a little together above ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! you look croſs—with all heart I'll go—one two, three, and away—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The little frippery, how ſhe carries it off!—Oh! the devil! I burn, I'm in a fever—I have had the graſs cut under my feet—Oh! the young Magdalen!—the ſly iniquity!—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Nature never deſigned me for a knight errant—Don Quixote would have ſtormed fifty caſtles, while my dull brain is hatching one poor project—what muſt be done?—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! ay! there he is, I ſee—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: 'Sdeath no way to convey a meſſage to her!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Full of miſchief!—your ſervant, Sir—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Mr. Lovibond!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I was in queſt of you.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: 'Tis a mark of your friendſhip—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I mean to prove my friendſhip, do you ſee—I don't like to ſee young men loſing their time—it is now fit you ſhould underſtand yourſelf, and fix upon ſomething that may ſettle your head a little—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Ah! Sir!—'tis in your power—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! much is in my power—I have a fair ward, Mr. Belford—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: He is going to propoſe her to me [aſide.] I know her perfectly, Sir—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Then I don't inform you of it—ſhe is handſome, ſpirited, and ſenſible—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I am no ſtranger to her merit—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Then I don't inform you of that neither; to-morrow I intend to gratify the wiſhes of her heart, and make her mine by marriage—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: What ſo ſoon, Sir?—this is news—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Then I inform you of it—and I will inform you of another thing too—She has a mortal averſion to you, and deſires you will trouble her no more —

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You amaze me, Sir—the devil! ſhe has not blabbed to him, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What a mortified countenance he puts on!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: This is all an abſolute riddle, Mr. Lovibond.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Then I'll unriddle it to you—ſhe perceived you dangling after her in all public places, whenever I took her abroad with me;—ſhe underſtood thoſe artful glances you caſt towards her; ſhe
could interpret every amourous ſigh;—ſhe bid me tell you ſo—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: She did?—then perhaps I know how to interpret her meaning.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: She ſays you may think her a melancholy priſoner, but you may ſpare your walks up and down the ſtreet; and ſo ſhe would have acquainted you long ago, but ſhe wanted a proper perſon to convey her ſentiments to you.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: She has found a truſty meſſenger at laſt.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ſo ſhe has—ſhe knows ſhe could truſt me—ha! ha!—I thought it a pity you ſhould loſe any more time, and ſo now you may go and bow, and kneel, and make a monkey of yourſelf before ſome other window—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Since is ſo, Sir, I muſt ſubmit—her meaning is deeper than he is aware of.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Don't be diſhearten'd—you may ſucceed elſewhere—ſhe allows you to be of a very comely figure; a well proportioned perſon; but 'tis all loſt upon her; ſhe conſiders me as her father, and has no unnatural paſſion for profligate youngſters.—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I believe you, Sir—I deſiſt from all pretenſion;—I ſee this matter now in its true light;—and, Sir, I ſhall moleſt you no more; and in that determination I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Not ſo faſt;—another word—tho' you were to watch your time, and in my abſence ſcale the wall, and get in at the window, and entreat her to elope with you, ſhe ſtill would cleave to me.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: That I dare ſay—I'll try her tho'— [aſide]—I am perfectly ſatisfied, Sir—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And harkye;—you may come as often as you will about the houſe, ſhe will not exchange a word with you out of the window—nor ſettle any ſcheme with you—ha! ha! you ſee you are fully underſtood—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
I ſhall ever eſteem you as my friend, and I ſhall loſe no more time, that you may tell the lady
—ſhe ſhall never have reaſon to upbraid me again—and ſo you may aſſure her—ten thouſand bleſſings on her for this ſtratagem;—ſhe ſhall be mine this very night.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What a look of chagrin there was!—I have trained the girl up to this—ha! ha! Mary Ann will never have ſenſe enough to behave in this manner—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: A pretty ſort of jeopardy I have been in, maſter!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Traitor! let me ſee no more of you.

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: And are thoſe my thanks, Sir?—You'll be ſo good as to give me a diſcharge—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I wiſh I could give you a diſcharge of a culverin—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: I am not ſo extravagant in my expectations as to deſire that favour, Sir—Heav'n help me! I am more eaſily contented—Only juſt a ſmall arrear of wages, if you pleaſe, with a little daſh of a character for diligence, fidelity, and a ſmattering of what you call parts, if my maſter did not mar all upon occaſion, and leave now and then in danger of dangling by the neck for attempting to ſerve him—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You are a villain!

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: I am a fool!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Have not you betrayed me to Sir Theodore?—let him into my whole ſecret?—He knew nothing of my being in love in town here, but you muſt divulge it, and I muſt have him ſtorming at me in a rage and fury—I muſt have my beſt concerted ſchemes diſappointed by you—Begone, raſcal, I have done with you—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Mighty well, Sir!—what poſſeſſes him? only pleaſe, Sir, to ſettle that trifling balance—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Ha! Brumpton! give me joy—things begin to wear a better aſpect—I'll ſwear you are right—ha! ha! I intend for the future to be a laughing philoſopher too—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Philoſophy may go to Bridewell for ought I care, unleſs philoſophy could pimp for a body—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Hey! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Every thing's the matter—aſk that treacherous—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Mr. Belford, believe me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Hold you your tongue, Sir—no more of your—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—what out of temper! My affairs, Brumpton, are in a fair way—you, after a great deal of pains, may poſſibly be diſappointed, but I—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Po! po! this is all—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I have meſſages ſent me from the girl I adore, you rogue—ſhe points out my road to happineſs.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I'm not diſpos'd to laughter—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Pſhaw! man, never fret for little diſappointments—have you any difficulties? you have ſtrength to remove mountains—Ha! ha!—my dear Brumpton, you ſend meſſages, I am ſent to—you are diſappointed,—I am likely to ſucceed—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, Sir, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Not I, truly—If I muſt die, I'll die laughing, like Pierre in the tragedy, ha! ha!—You make a toil of a pleaſure, Brumpton; and love, which is to me joy and rapture, is to you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Damnation!—draw this moment—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
No—no—our tempers are very different—what, I'm in too high ſpirits, and you want to let me a little blood—you fret, I laugh—ha! ha!—
I'll leave you to recover your uſual ſpirits—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, this is inſupportable!—I have but one ſcheme left—Briſk, you muſt execute it directly—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: There is no diſguiſe neceſſary, I hope, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: No murmuring, ſcoundrel; follow me this inſtant—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: This will be an horſepond buſineſs, I fear, and a ducking will ſpoil my livery.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: It was well ſaid by an old philoſopher, when you are in a paſſion con over your alphabet.—I have done ſo, and have recovered my temper—walk in Mary Ann, walk in—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah!—you have not taken any notice of me ſince you came home—ah! I ſee you don't love me—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You are much miſtaken—I love you exceedingly—draw a chair—ſit down—Well! and how have you paſſed your time in my abſence?—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: As well as any thing.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Have you any news?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: News!—law, not I—fikins, I fib tho'—I have news to tell you—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Have you?—what is it, chicken?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Little kitten's dead.—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Indeed!—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! if you had ſeen all its pretty little tricks, and how it played about—It grieved me to loſe ſhe—but ſquirrel's well—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Is he?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Yes, and ſo is mackaw—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ay, that's good news—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Yes, and I have marked three ſhirts, and hemmed five handkerchiefs—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Mighty well! [pauſes, and looks at her earneſtly] Mary Ann,—this is a wide and dangerous world we live in—ſcandal, malice, and detraction are ever flying about,—conſtantly on the wing, and ſpreading pernicious tales to the ruin of every character.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: You frighten a body, you talk ſo—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Draw near, ſweet, draw near—you look charmingly—mind what I ſay—ſome impertinent neighbours have whiſpered—but I did not believe 'em—they have ſaid, that while I was in the country, a young gentleman frequented here, and was well received, Mary Ann—But I have laid a wager there was no foundation for any ſuch idle givings out—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: How much have you laid?—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Five pounds to four—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: All that!—make a hedge of it, as you did at the horſe-race—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Cauſe, you'll loſe—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Then there was a young gentleman here—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: As ſure as a gun—He was here for ever and for ever—morning, noon, and night—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: But, my little lambkin, did not I forbid any viſits?—I won't be certain, but if my memory does not fail me—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Oh! for a matter o'that, you may be certain—you did forbid it, ſure enough.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: And why was I diſobeyed, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! you would have done the ſame yourſelf—as the ſong ſays

div.l: Had you been in my place,
Why you'd ha' done the ſame.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Very prettily ſung—but explain, my ſweet—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: It's the ſurpriſingeſt thing in the world—I'll tell you all about it—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: That's right; let us hear—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I was ſitting in the balcony, thinking of no earthly thing, and he paſſed by on the other ſide of the way—Ah! he looked as handſome as an angel—and ſo he made me a low bow—I bluſhed up to my very ears, and ſo I got up, and made a low curteſy—and ſo he kiſſed his hand, and I could not help ſmiling at that, and ſo he bowed again and again, and I curteſyed again and again, and then he walked up the ſtreet, and down the ſtreet, and to and fro, and backwards and forwards; and would you believe it?—He did not miſs a time making me a bow with all the good nature in the world, and ſo I was as good natured as he, and if he had ſtaid all night long, I ſhould have ſtaid too, for I thought it would not be right to be out done in civility—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! thoſe damned bal •• nies, I always hated them—well! well! go on, Mary Ann.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Well, and ſo the next day a large, comely fat gentlewoman came to me, and ſhe had three or four band-boxes full of fine things, and ſhe ſaid ſhe had orders to give me my choice of charming lace, and charming ribbons,—Ay! and ſhe ſeemed very good-natured, and ſpoke in the prettieſt manner—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! the execrable bawd!—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: You are very pretty, my dear, ſays ſhe, but it's a pity you ſhould be mewed up here—and then ſhe offered me to take me home to her own houſe, and ſaid ſhe would dizen me out with diamonds, and then a lord would fall in love with me—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The infernal ſorcereſs!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
And then ſhe ſaid I had done a great deal of miſchief, and that I wounded a young gentleman terribly—Who, I wound any body, ſays I?—Yes, the gentleman I ſaw in the balcony—I was as ſorry as any thing I had hurt him, but I could not tell how it was, and ſhe ſaid it was my eyes, and that he
was ſhot thro' the heart, and would be dead and buried in two days time, if I did not ſee him—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! the damned agent of hell.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And then, could you think of her goodneſs? Indeed I can't help loving her for it—She offered me to go and meet the young gentleman at her houſe—I thanked her, and took it very kind—but I did not care to go to ſtrange places, and ſo I ſaid the gentleman might come here if he would—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! the travelling milliner! [aſide.] Well, and did he come?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: That he did ſure enough—and he ſaid the very ſight of me cured him of his wounds—Ah! I am ſure you can't blame me, for I could not let him die, ſo I could not—I almoſt cried my eyes out when little kitten died—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Brother Lovibond is right—ſhe has it I fear;—Oh! I dread the reſt.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah!—but you are angry now—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: No—not angry—well—how did he behave?—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! he had ſuch a pretty ſmile—and he gave me this twee—and he gave Bridget and Peter whole handfuls of money.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What did he ſay?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Oh! the prettieſt words in the world.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: But he did not touch you?—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: By goles, I beg your pardon for that, but he did, though—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I gueſſed ſo— [aſide.]—Go on—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: He kiſſed one a thouſand and a thouſand times—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Daggers! daggers! daggers!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And ſqueezed my hand ſo tenderly.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Poiſon! wormwood! wormwood!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: He took one round the neck—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I thought as much [aſide.]—proceed—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And round the waiſt, and he—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Now—now—it's all over—how I tremble!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: What's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Nothing—we ſhall have ſome rain—my corn ſhoots; that's all—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And he [ſhe ſmiles at him.] Ah! but I won't tell you—you'll be angry—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: No—no—no—I love you dearly, Mary Ann; [laughs uneaſily.] I do indeed—go on with your ſtory, go on—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Why then, he took my glove off, and almoſt eat my hand up with kiſſes—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: But was that all?—did you do nothing more to cure his wounds?—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Look you there now—you are angry—ought I to have done more?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: No;—enough of all conſcience;—but, are you ſure this was all?—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: He gave me this fan, and a pair of ear-rings; and I am ſure it was very civil of him to ſhew ſo much good nature to a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Mary Ann, Mary Ann, all his ſmooth words, all his tenderneſs, all his ſmiles, were baits to entrap you, to enſnare, to deceive you, abuſe you, ruin you—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! but he told me to the contrary, over and over, and over again—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I know the world, child—it was all for your deſtruction, to ſwallow you up in the jaws of ruin—go up to your room—all this ſhall be explained to you—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! but you are out of humour with a body.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Do as I bid you—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Yes, that's what I will—By goles, he's a ſweet gentleman, for all you, that's what he is [aſide.]

div.p: What an eſcape have I had! and yet her ingenuous manner of confeſſing all, gives me ſome hopes—I'll read her a lecture, and then I'll go and let Sir Theodore Brumpton know what a villain his ſon is—Oh! Mary Ann, Mary Ann.

div.head: ACT III.
div.p:
MY dear good nature, hold you your tongue!—You plead in vain, not a ſtep will I budge. [ſtriking his boſom] I am rock, and will be made a dupe no more;—well ſaid, my juſt reſentment; we know the world now, and will be led a devil's dance no longer—Bravo Briſk, now you are free, and your own man again—Service is a very unthankful office, and for the mere honour of—Pſhaw! pox!—now my honour muſt be heard—What will the world ſay of you, Mr. Briſk, you that have hitherto been the firſt footman in England, renowned for your parts and your abilities!—what give way now to a trifling difficulty? money is abſolutely neceſſary for your maſter's affairs, Mr. Oldcaſtle is his only reſource, and you have orders to apply for it directly—But my dear honour, you know what an empty bubble you are, and how often I have been kicked in your ſervice—The more glory, man;—If any body thinks it
worth his while to kick you, it's a ſign you are riſing in the world—thoſe are the true marks of a footman's genius; thoſe are the things that will raiſe you in the world, and make an exciſeman of you at laſt! Bravo! I kindle at the thought—I muſt go on; one effort more, Briſk, and then—But how! how! touch the caſh!—"My maſter is in the utmoſt diſtreſs, Sir, and will be for ever obliged to you"—Pſhaw! that will never do—I have a ſtratagem, and if I can but meet with maſter Oldcaſtle—ha! as luck will have it—courage Briſk!—here he comes—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What a diſcovery have I made!—I'll let his father, I'll let Sir Theodore know—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Oh! Sir!—I am glad I have met you at laſt—I have ſought you thro' the whole town—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You live with young Brumpton, don't you?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: The ſame, Sir—ſuch a tide of affairs coming upon him—ſuch an unforeſeen accident—poor Sir Theodore, Sir!—the good worthy gentleman, on his way from the country—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I underſtood he was in town—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: He was coming to town, Sir; we expected him every hour—and now the fatal news is arrived—He was taken ſuddenly ill, too great a fulneſs of blood—no aſſiſtance near—it happened on the road—no ſurgeon—no barber to bleed him—the poor gentleman expired—and in the moſt critical moment—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Carried off in this manner you ſay, and without having time to be ill!—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Yes, Sir;—without a ſingle conſultation of phyſicians!—It's very hard!—It's a pity he was in ſuch a haſte to die—but good ſometimes comes of evil, they ſay—The news has wrought a wonderful change in my young maſter—Sir Theodore had made a match for him in the country—a great match indeed!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ay! I heard of it—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: And yet the ſon, perverſe and obſtinate, was in love here in town,—that is, he fancied he was—with an inſignificant huſſey, and was determined to marry her, in oppoſition to his poor father.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I have heard of that too—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: But he is now ſhocked that he ſhould be ſuch a monſter of diſobedience, and he gives up all thought of this town lady—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: That's right—the good young man—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ay! the good young gentleman, indeed—He renounces her for ever, Sir, and is reſolved to go off immediately for the country, and after he has performed the laſt duty to the beſt of men, who is now no more, he is determined to pay that regard to his memory which he refuſed to his authority, when living, and marry no woman in the world but the woman deſigned for him by his father.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The good young man!—this is the beſt news I ever heard in my life [aſide] the good young man!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: But then his intention of going out of town, I fear, may be fruſtrated.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: As how! that muſt not be—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Why we were kept a little bare of caſh latterly, juſt to reduce him to a ſenſe of his duty—and now he wants wherewithal to diſcharge ſome little bills, before we ſet out for the country—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Why, I am indebted to Sir Theodore's eſtate—the intentions of the young man muſt not be fruſtrated—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Here, I have in a purſe here—Ha! ha! I ſhall get rid of a plague and a torment [aſide]—I can let him have a couple of hundreds— [holds out the purſe to him] and tell him he can't go out of town too ſoon—good lack! poor Sir Theodore—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: My ſon bid me ſpeak to him, and luckily here he is—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: [in amaze] Ye powers of heaven!—ye guardian Gods!—aſſiſt me! help me!—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: [in a mock tone] Angels and miniſters of grace! what a damned accident is this!—let us run away, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Hey! what's the matter?—what do the people ſtare at?—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am all over in a jelly! [drops the purſe] Briſk, ſupport me, lend me your arm—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I have not ſtrength—but crawling on the ground—he'll carry away your purſe—you know he always loved money— [Brisk makes towards the purſe]

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—in the name of wonder, what poſſeſſes you?—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Diſappear, for heaven's ſake, diſappear—I never did you wrong—I'll pay the money to your executor—I was advancing your ſon two hundred pounds in part-payment; I never ſaw a ghoſt in all my days before—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: What! do you think I'm dead, Mr. Oldcaſtle?—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: And be you alive?

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: As ſure as you are alive man—Ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I took you for a ghoſt [ſtriking Brisk with his cane] Sirrah, let that money alone—hold me, Sir Theodore, hold me,—I am ready to ſink into the earth [Goes up to him] they told me you was dead—that fellow Briſk—Hey! what are you running away with my money—ſcoundrel! villain! robber!

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: May be you are uſed to ghoſts, Sir; I can't ſtay in a place that's haunted.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Compoſe yourſelf; and let me underſtand this buſineſs—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: [laying hold of him] I proteſt you are alive—that ſon of yours! he kills his father, before he is dead—that abettor of his miſchiefs!—he told me you was carried off ſuddenly, and now my two hundred pounds is carried off ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I am thunder-ſtruck!—I am as much amazed as you was this moment!—You ſhock me, Mr. Oldcaſtle—Could my ſon engage in ſuch a ſcene of wickedneſs?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am ſorry to ſay it; but I fear he is a very wicked young man—they have impoſed upon me; he has robbed me—this money is got for the vileſt purpoſes, to enable him to fly in your face, and carry off a little wench that is not worth a groat.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Not worth a groat!—and he had the aſſurance to refer me to you-ſaid ſhe had an eſtate, that there was a borough upon it, and that you knew all the particulars.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Borough upon her eſtate!—ha! ha! yes, yes, I know the particulars; lackaday, Sir Theodore, who do you think ſhe is?—a milliner's 'prentice that has eloped from her miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: My blood fires at him—I am out of all patience Mr. Oldcaſtle—thus my family is to be diſgraced by a worthleſs hair-brained blockhead!—a milliner's 'prentice!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Even ſo!

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: The fool! the coxcomb! the—here, I'll pay you back your money—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: No, you need not do that—get it back from him—it will burn in his pocket—the ſooner he leaves the town the better; I ſhall be at eaſe, if I once hear he is gone—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Mr. Oldcaſtle, you are very good to feel ſo much concern in this affair—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Yes, I have a deep concern in it; but hark ye, Sir Theodore—don't let him know you had your information from me—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: No—you may depend upon me—not a ſyllable.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: When he is gone, I ſhall ſleep in peace—I ſaid I would do him a good turn with his father.

div.p: How my heart it beats!—poſt haſte—gallop! gallop! and no wonder; it's a dangerous experiment I have tried—could I but convey this letter—Mr. Belford then would know my meaning—huſh! here comes my turn-key!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well Harriet, I have executed your commiſſion—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: How did he receive it?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: He was very much mortified, tho' I thought I marked, as he went off, an odd ſort of a dry conſtrained ſmile.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But I ſhall have no more reaſon to complain of him, I hope.—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! I almoſt pitied the poor devil—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: He deſerves no pity, Mr. Lovibond—he is a ſad wretch—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I believe it—But he knows he was engaged in a vain purſuit;—he ſaid ſo himſelf, and bid me aſſure you he would loſe no more time.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: That revives me;—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: No—no—he will hardly come this way again.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I don't know what to ſay to that—I dread the contrary—I am afraid he will not renounce me for ever ſo eaſily as you may imagine—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And, pray, what reaſon have you for thinking ſo?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I have terrible proofs againſt him—while you was out he came again under my window.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I ran away at the ſight of him—but the window being open, he flung this little box into the room with a letter in it.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: A letter in it!—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, the wicked contriver! a letter in it—I ran to the window to throw it to him again, but he was gone, and then it occurred to me that it might not be quite ſo prudent to throw it into the ſtreet, leſt it ſhould fall into the hands of malicious people, who might miſinterpret appearances to my diſadvantage.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: That was wiſely judged.—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I have been ever ſince thinking that it ought to be returned, and if I had a proper perſon—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Who ſo proper as myſelf? let me have it.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: No—no—it would affront him more if delivered by a common porter.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Excuſe me, I am the fitteſt perſon—a letter in a box!—what contrivances they have!—I'll take care he ſhall have it, and he will look ſo ſilly when he perceives all his ſchemes are blaſted.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
