sp.p: Why indeed, it will aſtoniſh him the more, if you deliver it—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: So it will—ha! ha!—it will be a rare ſtroke of revenge—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: [ſhe laughs] The neweſt that ever was—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I like it of all things—but firſt let me ſee the contents of his letter—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Dear heart, not for the world—would you give the horrid man room to imagine that a girl of character would ſo much as open the ſeal of his filthy letter?—let me adviſe, Mr. Lovibond; to return it unopened will be the ſtrongeſt mark of contempt, and the greateſt affront that can be put upon him—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: There is ſomething in that—your wiſdom charms me—you endear yourſelf to me more and more every hour—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: You'll uſe your own diſcretion whether to open it or not—But the reaſons I have given—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Are to me concluſive—I'll about this buſineſs directly—ha! ha! we'll put the greateſt affront in the world upon him—ha! ha! the trueſt mark of contempt, ha! ha! good-by, roſe-bud, good-by.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, yes, let him have it unopened—If this plot takes, I ſhall have my utmoſt wiſh—and making him my convenient, my go-between in the buſineſs, gives life and ſpirit to the plot—I'll outwit him, if I can—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Admirably managed, Briſk! now I have the ſinews of war — toſſing up a purſe.

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: It was got out of the fire, I promiſe you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Your ſervices are of higher value for it—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And yet I fear my ſervices may one day or other bring me to—What do you think your father will ſay to me?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Po! abſurd—Mr. Oldcaſtle will talk matters over with him—I deſired my father to make it his buſineſs to ſee my friend Oldcaſtle—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: You deſired him to do that, did you?—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Yes, I deſired him—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: And his coming was owing to you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Yes, yes;—ha! ha!—it was I occaſioned that—I deſired him to go—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p:
Then pray deſire any body elſe but Briſk to go on your errands for the future—more misfortunes!—here comes Sir Theodore; ſettle it as well as
you can with him—I waſh my hands of it, and now legs do your office.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: So, Sir! [pauſes, and looks at him] Thou graceleſs!—thou ungrateful!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: What's in the wind now?

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Eaſy, calm unfeeling prodigal!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Sir, theſe are words that—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: That you deſerve, and worſe, if indignation did not choak them here—look ye, Sir, I ſpared no pains in your education;—expence, indulgence, care, affection, all that a fond father could beſtow, were yours—I hoped to ſee you a young man of principle, governed by ſentiments of honour, a credit, and a comfort to me—but what a ſad reverſe of all this!—Your reputation gone, your character blaſted, and vile expedients every day made uſe of.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, this bitterneſs of reproach—how have I deſerved—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: How deſerved!— [pauſes, and looks at him] and dare you aſk the queſtion?—refund that money, Sir,—the two hundred pounds, out of which you have gulled an eaſy worthy friend of mine—reſtore it this moment, or perhaps it may be the laſt you will ever handle—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And where is the mighty harm, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I have no patience with you—I have lived too long for you, have I?—The ſand lingers in the glaſs, and you want to ſhake it out!—return that money this inſtant, or never look me in the face again—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: If it muſt be ſo, Sir,—but if you will pleaſe to hear me—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
Po! po!—I have full conviction—for the meaneſt purpoſes too this ſtratagem was contrived!—to run counter to my will, and carry off a little obſcure girl—and ſo live deſpiſed—a ſcandal to your father, and a laughing ſtock to all your acquaintance
—go, and reform, ſet out for the country directly, or never darken my doors again—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: What the devil can I make of all this!—I am certainly out of luck to-day—It does not ſignify—I'll purſue Mary Ann with more ſpirit than ever—I'll to her houſe this moment,—ſince difficulties come in my way, genius muſt ſurmount them, that's all.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: A mortal ſin!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Yes, a mortal ſin!—you are unexperienced in theſe matters—It is a ſin, child, to accept of preſents from men, twees, fans, and Bruſſels lace,—Bruſſels lace has done as much miſchief as the forbidden fruit—I wiſh I had bred her up a Quaker aſide mind my words—to indulge wanton young men in liberties with your perſon,—to let 'em fold you round the waiſt, play with your neck, and print laſcivious kiſſes on your lips, 'tis the ſure road to deſtruction—'tis horrible, Mary Ann, horrible and abominable—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! but I don't believe that—and a pity it ſhould, for [ſmiling at him] it's very agreeable—I am ſure I like it better than queſtions and commands, or the fool in the middle, or hide and go ſeek, either —

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I tell you they are all abominable things till the marriage-ceremony is performed—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And is it allowed then?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Then, and then only, Mary Ann—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [ſmiling.] By goles, I am glad to hear that, and ſo marry me as ſoon as you will—I ſhall be pure and happy with him, then—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Why, with that ſweet charming young—Ah! look you there—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Hold, beware, Mary Ann—I marry you for myſelf only—you muſt deſpiſe and deteſt all others—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! I never ſhall find it in my heart to hate him—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: It will be the deſtruction of you even to think of him—Look you, child; mark well my admonitions— [ſits down.] Come hither—hold up your head, child,—Liſten attentively— [he raiſes her head.] I take you to my bed, Mary Ann, my true and lawful wife—But take heed—for but now you was tumbling headlong down the gulph of perdition—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I wiſh you would let me go and feed my birds.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Compoſe your thoughts, I ſay—Marriage is an holy inſtitution, and exacts rigorous duties on the part of the wife—you muſt love, honour, and obey your huſband, therefore be upon your guard—the enemy of womankind is for ever prowling about in queſt of prey, always ready to ſeduce, to murder, and devour, and ſwallow up in the jaws of ruin every frail young creature that comes in his way—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [burſts into tears.] But they ſhan't ſwallow me up, ſo they ſhan't—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ay! ay! this will do her good—Come, come, dry up your tears

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [ſobbing.] I did not do any thing to be run away with in the jaws of ruin, ſo I did not—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: No—no—all will be well—'tis for your good I ſpeak—ſo—ſo—ſo—have done crying—I know you'll be good—there—make me a curteſy—mighty well—be a good girl—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! but they ſhan't murder, and devour me, for there are folks enough in London all hours of the day to aſſiſt a body; and if he comes in the night, I can call the watch, ſo I can—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am pleaſed with her ſimplicity—This young profligate that you have let into my houſe, if he ſhould c • me under your window again—That's right—I have a thought—you ſhall fling him out all his preſents—you ſhall write him a letter, and tell him what a monſter he is,—Come, take that chair—ſit down—take that pen, and write as I dictate to you—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [ſitting down.] Law! I does not underſtand all this—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: [walking about.] Write as I dictate—Come, begin—Mr. Brumpton [goes to the ſide of the ſcene.] Peter, bring me up a candle—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: "Dear Mr. Brumpton!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Mr. Brumpton, and no more—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [ſmiling aſide]—Very well—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: [walking about.] You are a vile man, and your viſits I now ſee ſprung from a bad deſign—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [aſide.] Ah! I don't like thoſe words—By goles [ſmiling as his back is turned.] I know what I'll do— [ſtifling a laugh.] I have wrote it—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: To ruin my future happineſs—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Happineſs—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Your intention is baſe,—and unworthy of a gentleman—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Very well—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You are odious in your perſon;—deteſtable in your morals—and the ſcorn of all our ſex—have you wrote it?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Stay—ſtay—then—all our ſex—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am in love with Mr. Biddulph.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Write as I bid you—I am in love with Mr. Biddulph,—a worthy good gentleman—and out of his hands—it never ſhall be in your power—to ſeduce me—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [ſmiling.] Very well—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Therefore let me never ſee you any more—Mary Ann Richley.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Mary Ann Richley—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Now let me read it—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah!—ſtay, ſtay a moment—Not quite done—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Here be the candle, maſter—the gentleman is walking under the window now—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Is he?—make haſte—fold up the letter—let me do it—let me do it, make haſte—come, come, diſpatch, he'll be gone, elſe—you ſhall throw it to him now, and all his preſents—come, come, make haſte.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! I am ready—I like this of all things—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Once more well met, Sir.—You can write I fancy, can't you?—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: The drift of that queſtion, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I fancy you know this little bauble— ſhewing a box. You don't know it to be ſure, no, nor the letter in the inſide—here take it back—I charge nothing for the poſtage—you have it unopened, in ſtatu quo— [opens the box.] Look ye here; ha!—no direction upon it—that was cunning—here, here, you have it in good order, and well conditioned as it came—ha! ha!—Harriet will not read a word of it—ſhe had no curioſity about it—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: But I have [aſide, and taking the letter, opens it.] heavens bleſs her wit—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! You know the hand-writing—Take notice you broke the ſeal yourſelf—none of us read a word of it—We return it unopened, to make the affront the deeper.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I believe you, Sir—I ſee you never read a word of it—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable—her pride would not ſuffer it—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Well, ſince it is come to this, being out of humour will avail nothing—Ha! ha! I can't help laughing—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: That's pleaſant of you—Ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Yes, very pleaſant—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: See what your intrigues are come to—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—you have brought 'em to a fine paſs—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay!—you ſee I am not to be tricked—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Mr. Lovibond, I am wild with joy—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And ſo am I—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Who is that old fellow?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I have managed matters charmingly—Who is that ſpark?—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: You need not be ſhy of him—I'll venture to ſay you have not managed as well as I have, Mr. Old—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Call me Biddulph.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well! I fancy you will toſs no more letters in at the window.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: No truly, Sir, not I—and I beg you will aſſure the lady that—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! let us hear—you need not mind this gentleman—come, come, let us hear—now brother Old—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Call me Biddulph—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! now hear him, Mr. Biddulph.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I beg the lady's pardon, Sir—I reſign, myſelf to her inclinations, and ſhall obey her commands—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Very well—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You are too powerful a rival, and ſince it is ſo, you will be pleaſed to tell her I moſt heartily approve of the choice ſhe has made—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Do you hear that?— to Oldcaſtle.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Her ſuperior ſenſe ſhines forth in every action of her life, and, Sir, I will only add that I ſhall never give her cauſe to complain again—you will report me to the lady, and, Sir, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: There, there, you ſee what an happy man I am—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Well, and now let me tell you

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I can't ſtay to hear—I am in the elements with joy—brother Oldcaſtle, your ſervant—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: But, brother Lovibond, let me tell you—po! an envious man, he can't bear a neighbour's happineſs—lackaday! I wiſh he had ſtaid, for here comes that graceleſs young—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Brumpton—the young dog, nothing affects him [aſide] Well, and your intrigues, how go they on?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Oh!—I longed to ſee you—you have not been able to reconcile my father, I find—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: No, I did all I could—I ſpoke very handſomely of you to Sir Theodore, I aſſure you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And yet he is worſe than ever—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: He is very poſitive—well! but the buſineſs of your love—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Why, it was likely to be ſomewhat embarraſſed—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I long to hear it. [aſide] As how pray?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: The old curmudgeon is returned from the country—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ay!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: The ſervants have changed their tone, and the door is ſhut in my face.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I can't help laughing—ha! ha! this Mr. Biddulph knows what he is about, I fancy—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Po!—the fellow is fitter to have the funeral ſervice read over him than the marriage ceremony—he made her come to the balcony—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Well! and how was that?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: He muffled himſelf up behind the curtain,—I could not diſtinguiſh him—ſhe threw me out ſome trinkets, I had given her—But, my dear friend, ſhe flung a letter with 'em—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I long to hear about that—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: The contents of it amazed me—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I dare ſay—ſhe told you her mind, I reckon—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Moſt freely, moſt openly—ha! ha! old Noſtrodamus is outwitted—for, look you here—here in her own fair hand—ten thouſand bleſſings on her [kiſſes the letter] Here, Sir, the genuine dictates of her heart—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: He is mad, ſure!—let me ſee it—

p.q: Dear Mr. Brumpton, you are a charming man, and your civilities, I am ſure ſprung, from an honeſt deſign, for my future happineſs.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: In the name of wonder, what is all this!

p.q: Your intentions are generous, and worthy of a gentleman—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The little hypocritical ſorcereſs!

p.q: You are handſome in your perſon,—and your manners alſo; and the admiration of all our ſex—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! the Jezebel!

p.q: I hate Mr. Biddulph, an odious old wretch; and

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The vile harlotry!

p.q:
And out of my guardian's hands, it is in your power to relieve me—Yours
indeed, and indeed, until death us do part—Mary Ann Richley.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: —She has reverſed every word of it!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: There's an adventure! ha! ha! ha!—is not ſhe a charming girl? you don't partake of my joy.—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Partake of your joy—I—I—I—yes.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: What a way old Biddulph will be in!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Why, I muſt ſay I feel for him—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Feel for him! a wretch like that!—ſo ungenerous a guardian,—ſo baſe a betrayer of his truſt! who could offer his withered ſuperannuated love to the ſweeteſt girl, and with the winter of old age nip ſo much beauty in its bud!—January and May joined together!—does not that make you laugh?—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am afraid of laughing, tho' I love it of all things—it ſets me a coughing always—well! but trouble may come of all this—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Never be uneaſy—an't you amazed at my ſucceſs?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am, indeed—I never was ſo confounded in all my days aſide I wiſh as heartily as a miniſter of ſtate that there was not ſuch a thing as pen, ink, and paper in the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: What's the matter with you?—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: A megrim has ſuddenly taken me—take care what you do—Mr. Oldcaſtle, you are a blockhead, an overweening, cuckoldy blockhead! [aſide]—I wiſh your father mayn't hear of this—Oh! the vile baggage, I muſt run home directly—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: How indifferent the old muckworm is grown!—but this dear enchanting letter!—Oh! this joy is too powerful—Sir Theodore never made this leg—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Brumpton, are you in good humour? May I venture to—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Belford, let me embrace you—I tread in air—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: My dear Brumpton, I too am wild with joy—I am out of my ſenſes— walks about humming a tune.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: [hums a different tune.]—Oh! ſuch an unexpected, tranſporting, raviſhing event—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Such a ſurprize, above all romance—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Oh! Belford, I am the happieſt rogue.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Such unutterable bliſs, my dear boy—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Her wit is equal to her beauty—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: The greateſt ſtroke of invention,—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Such a ſweet epiſtle—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: So divine a letter—and the old fellow brought it himſelf—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: No—no—you miſtake; ſhe flung it out of the window.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Po!—I tell you he was the bearer of it himſelf—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You are quite wrong; ſhe was in the balcony, and—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Pſhaw! give me leave to know—did not I ſee him?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: There was no ſeeing him diſtinctly;—he was ſkulking behind the curtain—and then ſhe threw the letter down to me,—Oh! the idol of my heart!—the lovely Mary Ann!—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Mary Ann!—you are the moſt perplexing—'ſdeath! I was telling you how my ſweet goddeſs contrived to ſend me a letter by her very guardian—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I did not hear a ſyllable of that matter—I was telling you—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Then I'll tell you how it was—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: No—no—hear the ſtory of my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Nay, nay; mine is the moſt ſurprizing.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Look ye here, my boy [ſhewing a letter.]—the work of her own fingers!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: There, there— [ſhewing his letter] more eloquence than in all Cicero.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: [reads.] Dear Mr. Brumpton, you are a ſweet man, and your civilities—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: [reads.] You will be ſurprized at this letter; and more ſo at the manner of conveying it.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: [reads] The admiration of all our ſex.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: [reads.] But I muſt hazard all, or fall a ſacrifice to the avarice of my guardian—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: [reads.] And out of his hands it is in your power to relieve me—
sp.stage: both reading at the ſame time very eagerly.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: [reads.] I love you, Mr. Belford; will you deſpiſe me for telling you ſo? I hope not.
sp.stage: both reading at the ſame time very eagerly.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: [reads.] Yours indeed, and indeed, until death us do part, Mary Ann Richley.
sp.stage: both reading at the ſame time very eagerly.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: [reads.] Contrive ſome means for my eſcape, and heaven and earth combined ſhall not keep you from me—the diſconſolate Harriet.
sp.stage: both reading at the ſame time very eagerly.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: YES, ſhe told me all about the young rake-hell's viſits, gave me back his letter unopened, to return it to him with my own hands—Is not ſhe a miracle of goodneſs and ſuperior ſenſe?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: It was very ſenſible—how often will you aſk me?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Is not ſhe trained up in the paths that ſhe ſhould walk?—When will Mary Ann do as much?—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ay! there it ſtings!—He has heard all, and I am blown!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have ſeen my gentleman ſince—I have given him his letters;—told him what a mortal averſion ſhe has to him; and I warrant me, I have ſent him off with a flea in his ear.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I thought to ha' done the ſame by young Brumpton—but the minx has ſo bamboozled me!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: You ſeem diſturbed—ha! ha! mortified at my ſucceſs, I ſuppoſe—ha! ha!—or ſome fly-flap has caught Mary Ann, and ſhe, poor thing—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: He has hit the nail o'the head aſide.—You need not trouble your head about Mary Ann—leave her to my care, Sir—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: But, Mr. Oldcaſtle—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: But, brother Lovibond—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: You are the ſtrangeſt man—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Po! po! you have no friendſhip for any body.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: No friendſhip!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: None—all for yourſelf, and wiſhing for other people's misfortunes—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: This is your gratitude, Mr. Oldcaſtle—Did not I help you to a rich young ſpendthrift, who wanted a thouſand pounds; and did not he give you his bond, and then did not I make him draw a bill upon you for the money, and did not I bid you ſue him for both the bond and the bill? was not I a witneſs in the cauſe for you?—I'll have you indicted for ſubornation of perjury—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: If you go to that, who taught you to ſink ſhips in the chops of the channel?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And who ſhewed you the way to be an engroſſer of corn, and a foreſtaller of markets?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Your ſmuggling, Mr. Lovibond—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Your uſury, Mr. Oldcaſtle—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Mighty well—I ſee what it's come to—Theſe are the thanks I meet with—I, that firſt laid the ſcheme of keeping theſe girl's fortune all to ourſelves—Here ends all intercourſe between us; I break off; I have no more to ſay to you—and ſo now you know my reſolution—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! what a turmoil the poor man has put himſelf in!—ha! ha! Things are going wrong with him—I never ſhall be at reſt, till I ſee the bottom of all this—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: And look ye, Sir—If ever you preſume to meddle again between father and ſon—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I meddle, Sir, between—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: If ever again I lay my finger upon a ſingle act of yours—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Sir, if you would permit me, all this expence of paſſion might be ſaved—I have to be ſure been caught tripping a little or ſo; but it is never too late to take up; I have reflected upon the matter, and without any great pretence to more wiſdom than falls to the ſhare of the like of me—I have obtain'd
my diſmiſſion, and bid adieu to my maſter's ſervice for ever—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Quitted his ſervice, have you?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I am going down to my father's in the country—My father's in a very pretty way; has ſome very good farms, and ſo I think to ſettle there for the reſt of my days—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I am glad of this, ſirrah, and ſince you have left him, I forgive you, do you ſee;—here, here's ſomething to bear your expences down—I commend your reſolution much—But hark ye, Briſk—now you are going,—it will be honeſt of you to inform me,—it will make ſome amends for what is paſt—is my ſon really in love with this girl?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: At preſent he is, but law! Sir, if ſhe were once remov'd out of his way—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: That is what I have been thinking of—that would do the buſineſs, would not it?—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Moſt clearly, Sir—out of ſight, out of mind with him—If in return for your honour's goodneſs, by any little ſervice in my poor way—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I thank you, Briſk, I thank you—but there will be no occaſion for you—I have employed an elderly body, a good cunning matron-like woman, who underſtands the whole art of laying ſpringes for young damſels.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Nothing can be better imagined, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: She is to inſinuate herſelf into the houſe, as ſuch people know how to do—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: No doubt, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: And then when ſhe has allured my young madam abroad with her, ſhe ſhall then be ſo diſpoſed off, that he may beat the buſh long enough, before he finds her, I warrant him—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: You have hit upon the only way in the world, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: It is an honeſt artifice, Briſk, to reſcue the coxcomb from deſtruction—I wiſh you well, Briſk, I wiſh you well.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Health attend your honour!—So, here's a mine detected!—and my maſter is flying wild about the town, thinking it's all enchanted ground he treads, and at laſt he'll be blown up in the air—with all my heart let him; let him ſee how he looks when he comes down again—and yet—there again now, temptations are beginning their old trade—well, ſomething muſt be done, and ſo now mine away, Sir Theodore;—be as good a pioneer as you will, I warrant me I'll countermine you—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: It's pure lucky, Bridget, he did not find the gentleman in the cloſet—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: He lay cloſe all the time like a mouſe in a cheeſe—and maſter walked about the room, and gnawed his lip, and gnaſhed his teeth,—and gave the table an hugeous rap with his ſtick,—and fetched a deep groan, and did not ſay ſo much as one word, and then led Miſs Mary Ann out of the room—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: I'll tell you what, Bridget, it's all owing to his finding out the young gentleman's viſits here to miſs Mary Ann—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Yes, yes;—it ſtands to reaſon how it muſt be that—dear me! he locks poor miſs Mary Ann up here for all the world like an horſe in a pound, and I can't tell why or by reaſon whereof, not I—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Bridget—I underſtand theſe matters—he locks her up do you ſee, becauſe as why he is troubled with jealouſy—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: But how ſhould that enter his head?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Oh! that pops into his head, becauſe—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: What is jealouſy pray, Peter?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Dear heart, you are ſuch another—jealouſy, you may know, won't let a body ſleep—it's for all the world, like ſo many rats behind the wainſcot-,-I'll tell
you now by way of likeneſs—the gentleman you know gaved you a guinea—now putting caſe, any body was to come for to take away your guinea, do you ſee—that would put you in a paſſion would not it?—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Oh!—I underſtand it now—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: It's as like it as any thing—for ſee but here—Miſs Mary Ann is his guinea—and you know when a body wants to be fingering another man's money, what does he do then?—why he brings you down to ſizes an whole heap of London counſel, to quarrel about it, and abuſe one another, and be together by the ears for ever ſo many hours—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: I remember all that, and it's as like miſs Mary Ann as it can ſtare—but then I want to know why does not every body make the ſame fuſs, and lock his wife up too?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Po! you fool! that's becauſe every body does not love his wife as well as a guinea—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Then I underſtands the whole git of it—but law!—look ye there—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: It's maſter, as ſure as a gun—how he looks, Bridget!—let us get out of his way—
The perfidious jade!—what a trick ſhe has played me!—Oh! the little, treacherous—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Law! you look ſo ſtrange, you are enough to frighten a body—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Mary Ann, I have ſeen Mr. Brumpton—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Have you?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: He was wonderfully pleaſed with your letter—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [ſmiling aſide] By goles, I know why.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What did you ſay to him?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Say to him!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Did you write what I bid you?
Altered it a little bit!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: A good deal, I fancy.
By gingo, I played you that trick—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: And was not it baſe, to deceive your guardian, who loves you dearly, and intends to make you his wedded wife?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I could not find it in my heart to ſay the things you wanted me—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: And don't you conſider what a crime it is!—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: It was only to play upon you—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: But ſuch wicked letters, Mary Ann—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: It was you ſhewed me the way—how ſhould I have thought of ſuch a thing?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: That ſtings, that galls— [aſide.] But there are women, Mary Ann, who can write without being bid—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: What, all out of their own heads!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Even ſo—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And what do they write?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: They make aſſignations; inform their gallants, when their huſbands are to be from home;—they fix the time for amorous meetings, at routs and drums—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Routs and drums!—What be they?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Wicked aſſemblies!—where women loſe more than they can pay, and then pawn their perſons together with the huſband's honour, and ſo infamouſly pay off the debts they have contracted.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And then do the men toy and play, and take 'em round the waiſt—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ay!—then their point is gained—
That's comical enough.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: And then they fly wild about this town;—to the ſeducing gaieties of Vaux-hall and Ranelagh—

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Law! I never heard of thoſe—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p:
Ranelagh, child, is a wicked round of ſin, intrigue, and clandeſtine love; where crowds
gather together, ſtealing glances, exchanging letters, negotiating riotous pleaſures—Vaux-hall is a very Paradiſe of forbidden fruits, where ſhady walks exclude the conſcious day, and every blandiſhment of ſenſe, muſick, wine, and opportunity, conſpire to waken the voluptuous paſſions.
And muſt not Mary Ann ſee thoſe places?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: No—never—never, Mary Ann—Here—here is the marriage act for you to read—all young girls ought to have it by heart—This will teach them how unnatural it is to fall in love without the conſent of king, lords, and commons!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! but I can't ſtay for their leave—thy are too great folks for me to think of!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Take it up-ſtairs with you—It is a very edifying tract!—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Very well, I'll go— [as ſhe is going.] I'll go and try if I can't write a letter out of my own head—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: When ſhe has read the marriage act, ſhe will have a proper ſenſe of her duty. So Peter!—ſo Bridget!—walk in—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Now if I can tutor theſe to my mind—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: For the love of mercy, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: I'll never do ſo any more, maſter—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Come hither both—I am not angry—you are no ſtrangers to the affection I bear Mary Ann—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: No, that's for ſure—you love her as well as you do a guinea—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: How now, Malapert!

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: I am ſure Peter ſaid ſo—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: No—not I—for the varſal world!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What's the matter, Numſkulls!—Liſten to me—watch my houſe well;—and be ſure you neve let any powdered fops put a foot over the threſhold of my door—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Yes, Sir!

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: No, Sir!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: But the wily arts of young men;—Think of a gay embroidered coxcomb coming to you with a piteous look: "I languiſh for your miſtreſs; I die in her abſence; let me but ſee her, or elſe I have one foot in my grave already"—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Be gone about your buſineſs, fellow, ſays I—this is no place for you—My young miſtreſs deſires no ſuch trumpery.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Mighty well, Peter, it can't be better—But you, Mrs. Bridget, will take ſome compaſſion upon a poor dying ſwain—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Go farther a field, and ſet up the ſign of the horns ſomewhere elſe—do—no admittance for you here—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Charming, Bridget, charming—you do it wonderfully—But then ſays he "I'll lie down in the ſtreet, and there breathe my laſt—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: And then I run up to the garret-window, and ſouce a bucket of water on his head—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Excellent! excellent!—it will cool his paſſion for him—have a bucket of water always ready—Ha! ha! I ſhould like to ſee him ſtreaming like a river god in the ſtreet—I am delighted with you both—But then he comes with his damned bewitching gold—Here, Peter, to drink my health—Here Mrs. Bridget, to buy you ſome tea.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: We want none of your droſs—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: No—not we—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: That's right—ſhove me—puſh me away.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Go about your buſineſs, I ſay— both shoving him.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Money is the root of all evil both shoving him.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: As I could wiſh—that's right—never ſpare me—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: We hate you as we do a toad.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: You vile ugly thing.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: We can't endure the ſight of you—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: You midnight owl! you griping, miſerly, old—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: There, there, hold, hold—But here, ſays he, here's the money for you holding out money.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: I humbly thank your honour

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Villain! traitor! [ſtrikes him.] Is this your virtue at laſt?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Law! what's the matter? was not I to take it?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What have I been labouring all this time?—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: But you did not ſhew the money at firſt—I could have refuſed it ever ſo long, if I had not ſeen the colour of it.—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The way of the world—But you are never to take it—Money is the ruin of the world—It declares war,—it patches up a peace,—it makes lawyers ſpeak,—it makes ſome folks hold their tongues,—Go, and think of all this—
Yes, Sir!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: And remember you have no buſineſs with money—Come, and ſhut the ſtreet-door after me.

sp.speaker: Bridget. Peter.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I muſt pay a friendly viſit to brother Oldcaſtle—Ha! ha! I know things are going wrong with him—I muſt gratify my curioſity—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Brother Lovibond! I go on as I could wiſh—my family is all as exact as clock-work—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I am glad of it, for the laſt time I met you—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I beg your pardon,—but now, loll toll loll! I am completely happy.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: My dear old friend, I am glad I have met you—Oh! ſuch plague! ſuch vexation!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Mind him, brother Lovibond—you'll ſee what order my family is in—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I was at the houſe but a little while ſince, and—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: And no admittance, I warrant—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Oh! the damndeſt adventure—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: A bucket of water upon your head I reckon—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Not ſo bad as that—I got over the garden wall, and—the adventure is whimſical too—the ſervants immediately conducted me up ſtairs, and—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Conducted you up ſtairs!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—mind him brother Biddul—
Call me Oldcaſtle—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Come, come, liſten to this—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: But, pox take it—my uſual good fortune failed me—I was not in the room two minutes when old Stiff-rump came tottering up—no way for a retreat—I was obliged to ſkulk in a dark nook, where I was almoſt ſtifled—In he came, and the lovely angel immediately accoſted him in ſuch a tone of ſimplicity—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Simplicity—ha! ha!—well, well,—let us hear—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: The curmudgeon did not utter a ſyllable—walked about the room, fetched a deep groan,—banged the table with his cane,—took her by the arm,—and led her away with him—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! a narrow eſcape—brother Biddulph—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Call me Oldcaſtle, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! — Simplicity is an admirable preſervative of young girls—Ha! ha! well, young gentlemen, and how did all this end?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: His back was no ſooner turned, than I ſtole down ſtairs, tipt the ſervant a couple of guineas, and ſo got clear off.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: The old gentleman is going on delightfully — his family is all like clock-work!—ha! ha! ha! — I have ſatisfied my curioſity — a good day to you.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: This is a mortal ſtroke!—Oh! Peter! Peter! Is this his virtue? — this his contempt of money!—this his bucket of water!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: What a cruſty old Cent. per Cent. it is!

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Brumpton! — Well encountered—I have been in queſt of you this hour.—This is the very criſis of your fate, man.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Hey! how! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: A train of gunpowder is laid, and there is Sir Theodore with a lighted match ready to blow you to the moon.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Explain, my dear boy, explain.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Why then, in plain Engliſh—your father has hired one of the good women who are ſkilled in the trade of leading young virgins aſide:—She, by his directions, is to tempt the miſtreſs of your heart abroad, and then to convey her out of the kingdom, where ſhe will be loſt to you for ever.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! it ſhan't be. — I'll watch the houſe day and night. Where's that ſcoundrel Briſk?

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Poor fellow, it was from him I had this information; he is out of his wits about this buſineſs!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Out of his wits! he is always out of the way.—Not a moment to be loſt—I'll to my poſt directly.—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: My affairs are in a thriving way—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Succeſs attend you.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Oh! the devil! here's a piece of buſineſs.

div.stage: Enter Briſk, in Woman's Cloaths, with a Bundle under his Arm.
div.p: One puſh more, and then, Briſk, your toils are over—Come, that's the houſe.—As my maſter knows nothing of what I am about, I may have ſome chance to ſucceed here.—Now for a few ſuperannuated matron-like airs— [knocks at the door.]—I found out her mantua-maker by good luck, and ſo now I know my cue—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Did you want any body, pray? No admittance here!

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Yes, truly, young man—La!—I am ſo jaded with walking—Oh! ſuch a pain in my ſide—and my head! it perfectly ſwims again—I muſt in and reſt a bit—I have brought your young lady's wedding-gown.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: How! is not that ſhe?—Oh! the deceitful Machiavel in petticoats.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Why an you bring home her geers, that alters the caſe—walk in, Mrs.—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Ay! the little lady-bird will be as fine as an angel, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Oh! the damned decoy-duck, there ſhe goes ſure enough—I'll wait for her in the ſtreet—'Sdeath! ſhe may get her out of the back-door—I'll alarm the old fellow directly— [raps loudly.]—The old bawd ſhall be put in the ſtocks— [raps again.]—Fire, fire, fire! Maſter Biddulph—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What's the matter there?—Who raps at my door in this—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Mr. Biddulph, Mr. Biddulph—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What do you want?—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You'll be robbed of your treaſure, of all your heart holds dear — Miſs Mary Ann will be ſtole from you—an old bawd will carry her off—ſhe's in your houſe now—now—now—now—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: A bawd in my houſe? — I'll ferret her out, I warrant me—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Now, Sir Theodore, what becomes of your intrigue?—Bravo, Brumpton!—this is well managed.

div.stage: Enter Briſk, and Oldcaſtle beating him.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Abominable procureſs! — Horrible ſorcereſs!—
Agent of darkneſs!—Miniſter of iniquity!

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Nay, good gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Vile ſeducer!—Deteſtable pandar!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Poacher of young game!—Kidnapper of innocence!

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake!—I'm down o' my knees—have a little mercy!—

sp.speaker: Oldaſtle.
sp.p: Thou gipſy!—Thou witch of Endor!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Get upon your broomſtick and fly away to Lapland!—

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: The devil's in the man, he will ſpoil all— [throwing off his woman's apparel.]—Nay, then, ſince you go to that—your ſervant, maſter!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Confuſion! what have I been doing?

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: You have been in luck as well as I, maſter!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: A footman in petticoats all this time! Thou vile impoſtor!—Thou Newgate-bird. [beats him again.]

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Wounds! maſter Oldcaſtle all this time! nay, then I muſt pretend— [aſide.]—How dare a ſervant of mine, raſcal— [beats him.]

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: Wounds! Sir, it was in your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Who gave you orders, villain!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: That's right!—Who gave you orders!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: By what authority!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Produce your authority!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: To take ſuch liberties with your maſter.

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: I ſhall take the liberty to leave him for ever!— [runs off.]

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: This is delightful! this is charming! The villain will come no more—he has paid the piper!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: A ſcoundrel to behave in this manner! Oh, ho, ho! ſuch an incident!— [in a fit of laughing.]—An unlucky dog I am—Poor Briſk, oh, ho!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Mr. Brumpton!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Mr. Oldcaſtle! What, are you Mr. Biddulph all this time?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You ſee what plague and vexation you was bringing upon your friend—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: My dear ſir, why did you not tell me at firſt!—If I had known that I was all this time treſpaſſing upon your ground—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p:
You ſee what a ſcene of iniquity you have been engaged in!—But ſince you perceive
your error, I am pacified.—This diſcovery is lucky—it will make an end of all.—I'll tell you what, you ſhall come and explain your miſtake to Mary Ann this moment.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: With the utmoſt pleaſure, Sir, and wiſhing her all happineſs, I will bid her farewel for ever.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: That will be right—you ſhall tell her that you repent, — that you now renounce all wicked projects, and are convinced it would be the ruin of her to marry you.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Lead the way, Sir; I am ready to obey your commands.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Very well! enough ſaid—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: One dear interview!—Bravo! Brumpton! you're in luck.
What do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Only that—you'll make a fair report of me to Sir Theodore—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ay! ay! that I'll do—come along—

div.stage: Enter Mary Ann in the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: La!—there's Mr. Brumpton with him—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You baggage, what do you do there?—Get you in—Did not you hear the people cry fire?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Aye!—but they cry ſo many things in London, I did not mind that—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Get you in, and never be ſeen in a balcony again!—It was there you ſaw her firſt, Mr. Brumpton;—ha! ha!—I'll have it taken down—Come along.

div.p: By goles this is pure—he is bringing him to ſee me—I have writ another letter ſince he has taught me that trick himſelf!—and now I'll give it him if I can—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Mary Ann, I have brought the gentleman with me.—He came to aſk your pardon, and to tell you that he was going to be the ruin of you—Tell it to her yourſelf, Mr. Brumpton.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I am ſure I forgive him with all my heart, ſo I do.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Speak to her, Mr. Brumpton, ſpeak to her—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Madam, I did not know what liberties I was taking with my friend,—and though my conduct was inſpired by real love, and your reſiſtleſs charms—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Pſhaw! that's all preamble—to the point at once—You had a mind to ruin her, ſay ſo without mincing it—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I muſt now renounce all farther pretenſions,—ſince to adore you any longer would be a violation of friendſhip, and an injury to this worthy gentleman, who has been intimate with my father for fifty years—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You may paſs that by—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! he's a falſe man, and I don't love him—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: So that I moſt humbly beg your pardon—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Go on, go on—
sp.stage: he is ſeized with a fit of coughing.

sp.p: And though I ſhall never efface your loved idea from my mind—
sp.stage: he kiſſes his hand to her.

sp.p: You have my pardon, I told you ſo already.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! lord! lord!
[recovering himſelf.] Well, have you told her you have done with her for ever?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Yes, I have got ſo far—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Very well! Now, Mary Ann, on your part, let him know your mind.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Muſt I ſay all out of my own head?

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ay! ay! tell him all—I wiſh brother Lovibond was witneſs to this!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I am very glad you came to ſpeak to me, Sir, and I underſtand you very well.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: But a little more at large—Tell him whom you chuſe for an huſband.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Why, here are two lovers, for whom I have very different ſentiments—I love one of them— [frowning at Oldcaſtle.]—and— [ſmiling at Brumpton.]—I hate the other. The company of one is always agreeable— [to Oldcaſtle ſullenly.]—and— [ſmiling at Brumpton.]—I don't care if I never ſee the other's face.—I ſhould like to be married to one of them— [to Oldcaſtle.]—and— [ſmiling to Brumpton.]—I had as ſoon be gibbetted, as be married to the other.—But my own Mr. Oldcaſtle— [toys and plays with him, then turning to Brumpton.]—I love you of all things.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You have won my heart.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: But do you forgive I every thing now?—Ah! you don't love me. ſings 'Go Naughty Man,' and reaches a letter to Brumpton.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I do—in troth I do—ha! ha! ha!—Mr. Brumpton, you ſee I have not ſuggeſted a word—all the dictates of her own heart—
All from the very bottom of my heart!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Since I underſtand you, Ma'am, I ſhall remove the hated object from your ſight.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: The ſooner the better.
sp.stage: then turns and plays with Oldcaſtle.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Mr. Oldcaſtle, I have the honour, Sir, to wiſh you all happineſs.—And I fly this moment to put your commands in execution, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: You can't go about it too faſt.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You may rely upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And don't let me be unhappy any more.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You may depend upon me.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: So—ſo—now I'll attend you down.—Po!—no ceremony.—You have made me happy, Mr. Brumpton—you have made Mary Ann happy.—Come, I'll let you out, Mr. Brumpton.
I attend you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: By goles, he has taught me a little wit himſelf; and if Mr. Brumpton follows my directions, I ſhall be pure and happy at laſt.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: HUSH!—don't ſpeak ſo loud, you'll give the alarm elſe to my keepers below ſtairs, and all is ruin'd—I don't know what to ſay, Mr. Bellford;—my heart begins to fail me—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: But after ſurmounting every difficulty, now in this laſt ſtage of the buſineſs to let your ſpirits ſink, would be ſuch a falling off from the character you have ſupported this day;—a character that ſurpaſſes all the heroines in romance, both for ſpirit and contrivance.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: The difficulties I had to encounter rouzed my ſpirits for a while, juſt as fits give us for the time, more than our natural ſtrength;—but now the conflict's over, my reſolution ſtaggers, and I am at full leiſure to feel the weakneſs of my condition—I can't go through it, Mr. Bellford, I can't indeed—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Nay, ſummon up your reſolution—Our mutual vows, the happineſs that waits us, every motive, a thouſand things conſpire, and call for all the conſtancy you are miſtreſs of—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But then to break through all the proprieties of conduct—all the decencies which my ſex requires—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: In a caſe like yours, the means are juſt which ſave you from deſtruction—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I tremble for the event—I ſhan't be able to eſcape—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p:
Truſt yourſelf to me, my love—'tis but an eaſy ſtep out of the window down upon the leads, and then through the neighbouring houſe—the people
are in my intereſt—come, reſume your courage—you cannot doubt my honour—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But the cenſure of the world—nay, your own opinion of me—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: The world will admire your ſpirit, and when 'tis known, that the old gentleman was your dupe, and carried on the plot himſelf, your invention will be applauded every where—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Why, I can almoſt laugh at him even now— [hears Lovibond coming.] Deliver me!—what ſhall I do? undone!—detected!—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: This is the conſequence of delaying too long—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Run into this room;—make haſte—diſpatch [ſhuts him in] and to make ſafe work— Puts the key in her pocket.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Harriet, I am never happy but in your company—the minutes move with leaden feet, when I am out of your preſence—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: And yet, you ill-natured man!—you can contrive to be out more than half the day—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Chide me not;—you'll break my heart if you do—every frown on that face is a death-warrant, and every ſmile is benefit of clergy—come, come, brighten up into happineſs and love.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: You know your power over me—you can do what you pleaſe with your own Harriet!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Can I?—you are too good.—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Where have you been all this time?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have been—but you look pale—what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Occaſioned by fretting at your abſence—and that hideous man keeps me in a conſtant alarm—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Don't waſte a thought on him—he'll trouble you no more—tho', to do him juſtice, I believe his intentions were honourable—poor devil!—
ha! ha! I fancy he loves you dearly—Well! but—poor brother Oldcaſtle!—your ſiſter has ſo bamboozled him—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: My ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: She has admitted a young gentleman to viſit her—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: She could not be ſo wicked!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: The girl has not erred ſo much from an evil diſpoſition, as from ignorance—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: A very ſmall ſhare of ſenſe, Mr. Lovibond, will give ſufficient intimations of our duty—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Very true—now the like of you, would not have done ſuch a thing for the world!—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Not to be empreſs of the univerſe—The young men of this age are ſuch a profligate race.—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: You are fit to inſtruct grey hairs—the young gentleman—one Mr. Brumpton—a wild fiery young ſpark—he was in the very houſe with her, and ſhe hid him in the cloſet—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: In the cloſet! well! after that, I will never own her for my ſiſter!—the wicked girl!—I am glad I have not viſited her—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—poor man!—he never ſuſpected any thing—had it been my caſe, I ſhould have ſmoked it in a moment—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Without doubt!—there is no impoſing upon you—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Oh! no—no ſuch thing—ha! ha! I can ſee thro' a millſtone—the eye of an eagle for a plot!—But come—come—it begins to grow late—come, let me hand you to your chamber, and then I'll lock you in ſafe from all harm till morning.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Heavens! what ſhall I do now? [aſide] Huſh!—let me ſay a word to you firſt—don't ſpeak loud.—My ſiſter is indeed much worſe than you can conceive—I wiſh you would ſtep and bring Mr. Oldcaſtle hither directly.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Now! what occaſion can there be—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: She loves that Mr. Brumpton to diſtraction, and has actually made her eſcape, to follow the vile man.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Made her eſcape!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: She is in that room now—I have locked her in—ſuch wicked ſchemes as ſhe has in her head! She has told me all, and intends to marry this Mr. Brumpton: ſhe has found out that ſhe is of age, and ſays ſhe will be made a fool of no longer!—there's a ſpirit for you!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: A ſpirit indeed!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But I have ſecured her to prevent the diſgrace, to ward off the ruin—and—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: That was conſiderate of you—let me go and talk to the young vixen.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: No—no—that will ſpoil all—I have pretended to connive at all this—But the moſt prudent ſtep,—I have learned all my prudence, you know, from you—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! an apt ſcholar you have been!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: You are very good—but there is no time to be loſt—I would have you bring Mr. Oldcaſtle here directly, that he may find her in the very fact.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Very good!—and then I ſhall be able to do the poor man a ſervice, and make a jeſt of him into the bargain!—Keep her ſafe;—don't let her out—this will ſo torment him!—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I am glad my ſiſter has found a lover, and I hope ſhe'll marry him with all my heart.—Is he gone? [liſtens at the door.] Ay! I hear him lock the ſtreet-door after him—and now I'll venture to unlock this door.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Thou charming contriver!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh!—this new danger has given freſh vigour to my ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: And now, my angel, we'll make ſure of our happineſs—come, truſt yourſelf to my care—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: And yet—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Nay,—no more doubts—our paſſage to the next houſe is without difficulty, and then liberty is ours.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I never was better pleaſed in all my life—I burn with impatience to ſee him—ha! ha! I ſhall never be able to walk faſt enough—ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well met! I wanted to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! I am now the happieſt man on earth. My troubles with young Brumpton are all at an end, and Mary Ann is ſafe at home.—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! as he thinks, poor man! — ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You may laugh, but I ſhall like to ſee your plan ſucceed as well—what a dupe you will prove at laſt!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What a dupe you are now!—the bird is flown, man; Mary Ann has eloped—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! you make me laugh.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: How ſecure he is! ha! ha! he little dreams—I tell you ſhe is gone—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Always abſurd!
You are ruined, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—do you think I don't know better.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Don't alarm yourſelf, my angel—this is my houſe—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh! I ſhall certainly faint—

sp.speaker: Brumpton
sp.p: My dear Bellford—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Heavens! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Don't be frightened, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: No—this is a friend of mine—well! Brumpton, the buſineſs!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: My deareſt Bellford, this is the moſt critical moment of my life—I have bribed the ſervants—carried her off—ſhe is mine—mine for ever—will you give me a room in your houſe for this one night?—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Why this ceremony? you know you may command in my houſe—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What noiſe is that?—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: That's Brumpton, I know his voice—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I am frightened to death.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: The door opens, walk in, ma'am, walk in—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Light the lady up ſtairs!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Huſh! Let us hear him—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I am wild with love, with rapture, and ſucceſs!—I have carried her fairly off, in triumph, my dear boy! She was locked up in a cloſet, but I broke open the door—

sp.speaker: Bellford
sp.p: I give you joy—but my own happineſs calls—bring the lady as ſoon as you will—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: A thouſand thanks, my dear Bellford—Victoria! the prize is mine.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Are you convinced now!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am thunderſtruck—Robbery! Murder! I'll break open the door—Watchman, call a juſtice of peace—call Sir Theodore Brumpton—he lives juſt by—Mr. Oldcaſtle wants him—his ſon has robbed me—I'll alarm all the world! [raps at the door.] Robbery! ſhipwreck! deſtruction! ruin!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—he feels it now, and I am not ſorry for him—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am mad, I ſhall go diſtracted;—I ſhall end my days in Bedlam— [Enter a ſervant.] I would fain ſpeak a word here in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, my maſter is ſomewhat buſy, and—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am plundered—I muſt go in—oh! villain! villain!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—now will he ſee which can train up a young girl beſt.

div.stage: SCENE an Apartment in Bellford's Houſe.
div.p: What's all this noiſe!— [liſtens at the door.]—Ay! I hear his voice—How could my booby let him in? But I have lodged her ſafe, and this ſword ſhall maintain poſſeſſion—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Where is ſhe?—Where is the unfortunate!—Reſtore her directly, reſtore her to her two guardians—We come to demand her of you.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Yes, we demand her, Sir—we know ſhe is here—and therefore—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: My houſe is my caſtle, gentlemen, and nobody muſt offer—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I'll ſearch your houſe—I'll get a general warrant—She is an heireſs—a ward of the high court of Chancery—'tis a contempt; you'll be committed for it;—ſhe is our property, in law and equity—I claim her, I demand her; and I will have her.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: This is an unſeaſonable hour, gentlemen; to-morrow I ſhall be ready to anſwer your complaints; in the mean time, I muſt beg you will leave me in quiet poſſeſſion of my own houſe.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: But we are her guardians, Sir—both her guardians—the girl is under age!—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Mr. Lovibond, you are her guardian; and what then, Sir?—Both of ye ſcandalous betrayers of your truſt!-I know it all—each circumſtance—You would impoſe upon her tender years, that you may infamouſly plunder that property which was confided to your care!—
There is a cloud gathering!—We ſhall both be brought to a ſtrict account—I had better make up this matter, that I may enjoy my own Harriet in ſecurity—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You have run away with an heireſs, and by the law of the land—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: I have a right to her;—I know ſhe is of age, Sir, and it is my fixed reſolution to marry her; ſhe has declared in my favour, and nothing ſhall be a bar to my happineſs!
She is of age ſure enough; how did he find that out?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Better make the beſt of a bad bargain— [aſide.] — But let me underſtand you, Mr. Bellford;—do you intend to marry her yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: It is my peremptory reſolution.—But all in honour, Sir—marriage articles, for the purpoſe of ſettling her whole fortune upon herſelf, are now drawing in the next room.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I ſee what courſe I muſt take.—If he marries her, I ſhall live in peace.— [aſide.]—Mr. Oldcaſtle, the girl is of full age.—Let me ſay a word in your ear— [aſide to him.]—conſent to the marriage, and get a handſome allowance for the trouble and expence of her education—That word makes me laugh—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I am diſtracted; what ſhall I do?— [aſide.]—I thought young Brumpton was to marry her?

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: No Brumpton on earth ſhall rob me of her!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The trouble, and the fondneſs with which we have reared her—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: He will allow for that—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I have long lov'd her—Can't you reſign her now,—you will be the death of me elſe?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Think no more of her—ſhe is not worthy of your regard. Mr. Bellford will behave like a gentleman in matters of account, and—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Preſcribe your terms—I am ready to agree the matter this moment—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: A releaſe for the intereſt of rents and profits—a cool five thouſand for extraordinary trouble, and for her muſic-maſter and her dancing-maſter—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: He was her only maſter himſelf—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Agreed!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Cloſe with him—cloſe with him directly—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I wiſh you would reſign her to me—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: I will not defer my happineſs beyond tomorrow morning!—My lawyer is in the next room; let him draw up a memorandum between us, and your conditions are granted.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: It ſhall be done—we will both ſign—Come, don't heſitate.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I ſhall break my heart!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Po!—no heſitating,—come and finiſh the buſineſs!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle
sp.p: It is a terrible ſtroke!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Never ſtand debating—you have made the beſt of a bad bargain—loſe no time— forcing him along.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: But, Mr. Bellford—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: We muſt reſign her—we muſt give her up—Come along, man.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: I attend you, gentlemen—I agree to your propoſals.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Walk in, my angel; you are ſecure here.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Ha! Brumpton—I give you joy—I congratulate you too, ma'am—and—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I thank you kindly, ſir.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And now, Bellford, thro' the perils of this day we have both at laſt attained our utmoſt wiſhes. I could be merry about it, but I muſt give my fellow Briſk ſome directions. I have ſuch a ſtory to tell you—ha! ha!—I ſhall be with you in an inſtant.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: La! what a pretty room here is!

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Your appearance tells me, ma'am, that my friend Brumpton has found a treaſure.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I am ſure, I am fortunate in finding him—for I led ſuch a life; you can't think how diſmal!—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: The ſcene will now be changed, and the pleaſures of life will court you on every ſide.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! the little compound of treachery and fraud!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I was kept from morning to night mewed up at home, and he talked ſuch a parcel of bug-bears to frighten a body—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh the traitreſs!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
And he ſaid if I looked at a ſweet •••••
ing young gentleman, that I ſhould be 〈◊〉 , and devoured, and ſwallowed up!

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: An old blockhead!—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Yes, I thought as much—But I am ſure I am obliged to Peter and Bridget for letting me out, and they ſhall come and live with me, ſo they ſhall—Do you know our Peter and Bridget?—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: They ſhall both be hanged.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
And my old guardian wanted to marry me himſelf, but— [laughs.]—he talked in ſuch a
manner, and ſaid ſuch ſtrange things—But— [laughs.]—the joke was, he taught me how to write letters, and I ſhould never have thought of ſuch a thing had he not put me in the head on't—And he is ſo old, and totters about ſo; and he calls me his lambkin; and bids me read the marriage act, and a heap of trumpery.—An hideous, ugly, old ſcare crow!—La! there he is.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: I have ſigned, Mr. Bellford, and they wait for you.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: I ſhall give you no delay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Thou ſerpent, whom I have warmed and cheriſhed in my boſom!—you muſt ſting your benefactor at laſt, muſt you?—Did not I promiſe to marry you?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Yes, but by goles, I thank you for that tho'—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: And will you deſert me for a ſtranger?
He's a ſweet man!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Viper!—this is your ſimplicity, is it?—I, who loved you ſo—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah!—but his love is more agreeable by half.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well! now every thing is ſettled.—So, madam, you are there, are you?—ha! ha! Brother Oldcaſtle, I always told you how this would end—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: If ſhe had minded my inſtructions—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! Inſtructions!—You brought it all upon yourſelf—but 'tis better as it is—your head would have ached all the reſt of your days—ha! ha! ha!—I am heartily glad of this—ha! ha!—Come, Mr. Bellford, I'll give her away—here, take your wife—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Wounds! I can't ſtand this—I'll not be a witneſs.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: But you ſhall be a witneſs; you are a party concerned—you muſt come back.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Since they have agreed the matter, Harriet ſhall make her appearance.

div.p: What does all this mean!—Sure it can't be ſiſter Harriet he talks of.

sp.p: You muſt, you ſhall come back.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Don't be frightened—you are the object of my heart, and they will give you away.

sp.stage: [forcing in Oldcaſtle, without looking behind him.]
sp.p: You are a party to the agreement—you muſt ſee her given away.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Here's the lady. [leading her to Lovibond.]

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! ay! give me her hand— [without ſeeing her.]—you ſhall ſee the buſineſs done, Mr. Oldcaſtle.—Here, here—wounds! what's all this?—Harriet!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Huzza!—a reprieve!

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Ah! ſiſter there—what have you been writing letters too! [goes up to her.] I be glad to ſee you—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What does all this mean?—what brought you hither, Madam?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: My love for this gentleman. She takes Bellford by the hand.

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—ſhe is his wife all this time—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I was not by any means worthy of you, Sir—and ſo I have transferred my affections where I think they will be placed to advantage!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I am ready to ſink into the ground with amazement!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p:
Loll, toll, loll!—brother Lovibond!—you brought it all upon yourſelf—ha! ha! ha!—
I pity and laugh at you—ha! ha! this is the education you have given her—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I ſhall die upon the ſpot—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—I ſaw what it would all end in— [follows him about.] She would have been too young a wife for you, man—ha! ha!—I am heartily glad of it—here, here, I'll give her away—here Mr. Bellford, take your wife—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: I accept her at your hand—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: And I give you mine, with all my heart!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Now, who underſtands education?—Come, madam, come you home with me— taking hold of Mary Ann.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! but I can't do that, for I be married as well as you, ſiſter — [runs over to her.] he carried me to a parſon, and it was for all the world, like what you uſed to ſay [to Oldcaſtle] about love, honour, and obey—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho!—what a day of adventures have I had! but fortune has at laſt crowned me with ſucceſs—My good genius has attended me throughout—my ſweet, my lovely bride!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Brumpton!—what a life you have led me!

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Where is the graceleſs, the profligate, the abandoned!—So Sir! [to Brumpton.] why am I to be called out of my houſe on account of your midnight practices!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Theodore, I am glad you are come—your ſon will be the death of me!—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: What does all this mean, Sir!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: That I am married to this lady, Sir—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: He has robbed me of her;—plundered me;—he will go to the gallows for it—ſhe is an heireſs!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well! this is ſome comfort—ha! ha! brother Oldcaſtle, we are both in the ſame predicament.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: An heireſs ſay you?—George, give me your hand, ſince you have not thrown yourſelf away—and was it your ward all this time?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—ha! ha! ha!—this is the lady whom he called a milliner's prentice—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—and that was his fetch to deceive me, was it?—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—you have managed it charmingly—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: You'll drive me mad all of you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton. Sir Theodore. Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: This is pure comical;—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! I ſhall never ſurvive this!

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Nay, no uneaſineſs, Mr. Oldcaſtle.

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: I fancy we need not think any more of Hampſhire now. Sir Theodore!—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: What are you there, Briſk?—You have been a ſad rogue.

sp.speaker: Briſk.
sp.p: I have been working for the good of your family, Sir!—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: So you have; I forgive you all—George, I give you joy with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You ſee, Sir, I have married a fortune for the good of my children; and the lady's beauty I fancy won't offend you.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: No, I embrace her as my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Ah! you are very good, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Oldcaſtle, never be dejected—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! I have loſt a treaſure—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Yet you muſt excuſe me, Sir, when you recollect the letter the lady flung me out of the window!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Flung him a letter!—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And when you reflect, that you yourſelf brought me into her preſence to receive this letter, in which ſhe prays me to be her deliverer!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! the contriver of his own misfortunes!—Gave her the opportunity himſelf—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: And when you conſider, Mr. Lovibond, that you brought me Harriet's meſſages, and delivered me this letter with your own hand!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: How is this!—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: A declaration of my heart—I had nobody to carry it but you!—

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: The contriver of his own ruin! delivered her letter himſelf! ha! ha! how well he knows the world!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Bellford, give me your hand—and ſo we have been ſtruggling hard for two ſiſters all this time!—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: We have, and from henceforth ſhall live both friends and brothers!

sp.speaker: Oldcaſtle.
sp.p: Oh! Mary Ann!—you have deceived me, but I ſhall be glad to ſee you happy.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And I am ſure, I ſhall be always glad to ſee you, if you live theſe three years to come—Here's your marriage act for you! Siſter Harriet, la! I longed like any thing to ſee you—and I am glad we are both happy at laſt—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
A right uſe made of this event, will be of general ſervice to us all—To theſe gentlemen it may prove a School for Guardians, where they will
learn not to bring upon themſelves the reproach of a diſhoneſt, an amorous, and contemptible old age—We, Bellford, and theſe ladies, who are now embarked on a voyage for life,—we cannot fail of happineſs—

div.l: To youth ſure rapture marriage ever brings,
When from eſteem the happy union ſprings.
